I've said countless times, car chases and shoot outs pretty much bore me now (hence me having no interest in the Fast & Furious franchise) but the difference here is, you actually care about the characters and the situations they are in. Shame Black's script is superb and for me director Richard Donner (who is still the director of the best Superman movie) pulled off a master stroke with his casting.Both Mel Gibson and Danny Glover are superb in their roles, as is Gary Busey, Darlene Love, Steve Kahan as Captain Murphy and Mary Ellen Trainor as Dr. Stephanie Woods (the Police Psychiatrist) do well in their small roles. Glover had been superb in The Colour Purple and Places In The Heart, and Gibson was a star on the rise, who hadn't quite made it big in America. He got to be serious, funny, heartbroken, crazy and the object of someone's affection.If there is a weak link in the cast, it is Mitchell Ryan as General Peter McAllister who seems to be in full pantomime villain mode and Ed O Ross who has a small role. The editing of the final fight irritates me every time too, but that really is nit picking of the highest order. Composer Michael Kamen and Eric Claptons score is a winner too. I also like Traci Wolfe as Murtaugh's daughter who has a crush on Gibson's Riggs. Excellently directed with a great score, Lethal Weapon is almost perfect entertainment. It was Gibson's biggest hit to date, ending the year the 9th highest grossing movie of 1987 with a domestic gross of $65 million. Beating movies such as Dirty Dancing, Living Daylights, Robocop, Wall Street and Arnie movies Predator and Running Man. Interestingly though, the similar themed movie Stakeout (which I love) slightly out grossed it.

Review title: Lethal Weapon! A great action film!
Review_body: The Lethal Weapon series is an explosive and exciting one that is always exciting with a lot of action and great acting from the stars. There's Lethal Weapon 1, Lethal Weapon 2, Lethal Weapon 3, and Lethal Weapon 4 all starring great actors Mel Gibson and Danny Glover! Also Joe Pesci and Rene Russo are in the later editions! Steve Kahan and Paul Tuerpe are in all four as well. Shane Black did a great job with the writing! I also like how the series has the same composers Michael Clapton, and director Richard Donner has directed all four! Lethal Weapon is the one that started it all! It stars Mel Gibson, Danny Glover, and Gary Busey! Also in the movie is Mitch Ryan, Tom Atkins, Ed O'Ross, and Grand L. Bush. Look for Joan Severance, Sven-Ole Thorsen, Mic Rodgers, Peter DuPont, and Al Leong! There are some really neat action scenes and Gibson puts on an excellent performance! Good music by Michael Kamen and Eric Clapton! Looking for action and love Mel Gibson, Danny Glover, and Gary Busey? Watch Lethal Weapon today! I strongly recommend it!Movie Nuttball's NOTE:I noticed that Danny Glover, Gary Busey, and Steve Kahan were all in two movies together and they are Lethal Weapon and Predator 2! Interesting!

Review title: Mel Gibson likes action but with some social depth
Review_body: We are reaching here the roots of Mel Gibson. He is a cop without any equal and pairs with another cop who is only second but learns fast. The action is highly packed and intense and that is exactly what we want, what we like. But is action enough to make a good film? Of course not. The film is good first of all because of the small touches of humanity that are scattered all around, a dog as a best friend, a cat as a best buddy, and you can imagine the meeting of the two on Christmas day. A boat that has a front and a back and no water all around. Several kids who are as nice as kids know how to be when they are in a good mood, and we are surprised by the high level of resistance and resilience they demonstrate in the midst of that frantic action. A few black street boys who are deliciously anti-cop and just like ice cream so much that they start forgetting they are not supposed to speak to cops. A grenade that is a smoke bomb. A birthday that turns hectic with too many candles, definitely too many, on the cake. A shooting gallery that turns funny with bullets carving nice smiles into the faces of all the culprits in the world. And that and many more details make that film a real pleasure, nearly emotional. But the film is a lot better than that. When a country starts something dirty in the world against another country or another people, sooner or later the criminals that country has trained to do the bad job will come back to haunt everyone in their tombs or a little before they put them in their tombs. Killing machines are killing machines and you cannot stop them because you decide the war is over. That's why you should never start a war anywhere in the world, and those professional trained criminals can only be put to death because they will never accept any other trial or judgment, nor any period of peace and quiet at the bottom of a jail seen as an aquarium for gold fishes. They can only end fighting with real weapons and killed by real bullets, two rather than one, from two different guns rather than only one. That's what makes this film a lasting pleasure because in the world there is always the temptation to start a new war, and after starting a first one you cannot resist starting a second to spread the feast and the fun and make hundreds of thousands of people, in uniform or not, take part in the "danse macabre" that leads right to the cemetery, what's more an anonymous tomb of course, or just a collective grave, a big hole with some lye on top of the dismembered bodies. But we can end with the beginning then and imagine what the best friend dog and the best buddy cat do together when they meet. They do what human beings always do when they meet: they fight over their differences.Dr Jacques COULARDEAU, University Paris 1 Pantheon Sorbonne, University Paris 8 Saint Denis, University Paris 12 Créteil, CEGID

Review title: Periodically smart and generally wry in an entertaining sense, Lethal Weapon is a taut enough crime thriller with some likable lead characters broken down and explored.
Review_body: There is a great deal more fun to be had out of the combination of the two leads and their respective studies in 1987's Lethal Weapon than mostly anything else, their connection and the manner in which the two actors deliver the material much more interesting than whatever narrative or subplots to do with this, that or t'other which arise. By the time the film has descended into topless hard bodied males duking it out on a sodden lawn in a somewhat erotic display of masculinity and strength, the film has dealt humorously and substantially enough with how these two can't, in any way, feasibly link with one another given their respective life-situations at the respective point of meeting before having them gleefully link. The thrill is in the lead pairing and how the film observes that each needs the other one to advance to the next stage in both life and thinking; Lethal Weapon being really rather an intimate character study of two police officers, whom will end up on different roads as to when we first saw them, masquerading as an action picture. Director Richard Donner etches out as much as possible from these notions and idea before allowing the stunts and spectacle to just fill in the blanks along the way.Donner, in fact, opens the film with what is quite a long, remarkable tracking shot over the Los Angeles canopy layer of the numerous skyscrapers on show; the music bright and bubbly, your more typical establishing shot of a place so as to hammer home precisely where we all are on show. In the same take, the camera will descend into a high-rise building of apartments to reveal a semi-naked girl who takes some cocaine before leaping from a balcony and to her death. Just as the tone changes in the uncut crane shot, the atmosphere and content change with it; the greater extent of this wonderful opening being that it is how Donner will go on to construct the film, as a bright; airy and breezy piece with some harmless scenes of domesticisation and a carefree attitude to most scenes - granted, with a scene of suicidal ideation thrown in. But all this is before having everything descend into a more sordid, less glamorous zone when nastiness and sleaze come out of nowhere and now top the bill.The two lead's are both Sergeants, Mel Gibson's character is Martin Riggs while it is Danny Glover playing Roger Murtaugh. Their binary oppositional traits lie within their home-life, their attitudes to their work and just about everything else going on in their lives; eventual change and recognition as well as the opportunity to advance the end result. For Murtagh, his gradual getting by in the police department sees him attend crime scenes; take notes and generally do a lot of administrative work as he lives in the ideal detached house in a suburban part of California with the ideal family, an early scene in which they surprise him whilst he's in the bath outlining what a close knit group the Murtaugh's are as a background mirror reflecting his family hints at a literal 'reflecting' of a perfect family based unit. Roger is a Vietnam War veteran pushing fifty whom needs to be reminded that said war happened as long ago as it did and is having to come to terms with the growing up of his daughter Rianne (Wolfe), someone coming to be preoccupied with dressing up and going out in the evenings.On the jump side of things, Gibson's rough and messy trailer dwelling loner Martin Riggs is struggling with the recent death of his wife and is suicidal as a result; his much more 'hands on' police work when compared to Murtaugh's seeing him take gross, unnecessary risks with hardened criminals during a drug busts so as to further the possibility of on the spot release from life. Their pairing is the result of the aforementioned woman whom jumped from the balcony, something which is treated as a murder when traces of poison were found in the body upon investigation. Through being placed together, Riggs comes to observe a healthy family unit while gradually feeling better about himself while you feel Murtaugh comes to acknowledge his job a lot more after being involved in harsher, meaner police work as well as observing his own family and everything he's worked for become grossly threatened. By the end, Murtaugh has learnt to "shoot to kill" rather than just to do as before in maiming, as Riggs becomes more level headed the more he works with a family man. The thrill is in the way these two bounce off of one another, their respective life situations coming to compliment one another as changes are afoot whilst Riggs has some genuinely funny lines throughout.A plot involving a sadistic ex-American serviceman now turned evil mercenary and drug runner named Mr. Joshua (Busey), a man who is far more threatening than the name suggests, sees the two of them get in way over their heads but effectively renders their plight one of a fight against corruption and former patriots using their powers and abilities for wrong-doing. It's here the film becomes only a moderately interesting causality driven chase thriller, how Donner structures his film's opening shot only now resonating with us in its foreshadowing of something quite warm and welcoming becoming seedier and nastier as we delve in deeper with the peak of which is a pair of nasty interrogation sequences and some stark peril involving young Rianne. With a sharp and engaging more often than not screenplay from Shane Black, plus a competent job of direction from Richarcd Donner, Lethal Weapon is around about smart enough and entertaining enough to give a go.

Review title: A film that made history and left its marks, but it's not perfect.
Review_body: This film is one of the most interesting action films of the Eighties and started a brief, but interesting, film franchise. The key plot point is the collaboration and friendship between two substantially different policemen, but who have just been paired by their bosses: Murtaugh is an experienced middle-aged cop, disciplined in methods, married, a father and very attentive to his family ; Riggs is a police officer who has worked for several years in the Narcotics division and is experiencing severe depression, with suicidal tendencies that lead to impulsive, violent and risky behavior. Both are assigned to investigate the apparent suicide of a prostitute who is the daughter of a longtime friend of Murtaugh's, and who may be associated with a group of drug traffickers.In addition to the film having a good police story, the huge difference between the two protagonists and the way they manage to learn to respect and collaborate makes this film a good entertainment piece. It's not a movie made for thinking, nor is there a real mystery behind the crimes. It is an action-oriented film, punctuated by a light, intelligent and well-placed comedy. It's a movie made to enjoy and entertain.Much of the film's success rests on the back of its protagonist duo: Mel Gibson gives his character a bold, insane and intelligent aura, making good use of the opportunity and protagonism to popularize and leverage his career. Danny Glover is not far behind and offers us a mature, more restrained and intelligent performance. There are still several other actors, but none of them received material capable of allowing them to be highlighted.Technically, it's a regular action film, with elegant but understated cinematography, well-constructed sets and uninteresting costumes. The most notable technical aspect is the visual, special and sound effects department, which provides us with a job well done and realistic. There are lots of explosions, wrecked cars and insane fights that oscillate between the epic and the far-fetched, and the movie sometimes overdoes its spectacularity. The soundtrack is forgettable.

With the time, this movie started a lot of trends that are nowadays in all action movie. The funny thing is that those ideas come by pair of opposites:First, the buddy movie: the old timer teams up with a crazy hotshot and the mix is explosive. The former calm and dull pavilion life will be changed forever. The magic comes here from its formidable casting because Glover and Gibson fit the part like glove. Next, the big violent criminals and sexual arousal: it's evident here that the shootings and fights are more brutal that those we have previously seen in similar movies. The kills rise high as well as the nudity scenes (it's not a erotic movie but you see that the prude veil is starting to come down at the release). However, the pill passes up as this content is blended with very familial content as well and comedy.Now, the complicated and very unbelievable plots: as they laugh themselves of it ("it's thin", "anorexic"), the crime story isn't original or inventive but the movie is speedy, nervous and dynamic (maybe it's even a bit too fast because the edit is sometimes clumsy: look for the handcuffs just before the big jump or count the shots and compare them with the card!). Like the casting, Donner has been a good choice because he knows how to tell a story.At last, in this first movie, the more unexpected opposition comes to shoot the movie in LA at Christmas time. It's very unusual to see that and the movie has a good atmosphere coming from the Californian sun and the Christmas decorations!Quickly, a good mention goes to the daughter that I have unfortunately never saw in other big movies and to the late Nick Kamen who scored a very bluesy score that helps define the mood of the movie.As you have understood, it's a really good movie, full of juice and laughs and that calls for more!
Is it the greatest cop/buddy movie of all time?Yup

Review title: Infamous cop duo of Riggs and Murtaugh get it done
Review_body: Nothing says 1980s cop thriller like a story of two cops that don't want to work with each other being forced to work with each other, especially when one of them is black and the other is Mel Gibson with flowing hair.There's not much to say about "Lethal Weapon" other than it got it right. Riggs and Murtaugh (Gibson and Glover) are undeniably one of the top duos of all time. After all, their chemistry was spectacular enough to bring about three more sequels. But why does the aging, skeptical black man work well with the younger, reckless, suicidal white guy? It's this huge contrast that reaches a wide audience.Because of how different they are, both heroes connect to everyone, but it's really more about how they are one person split in two. We all have a more grounded perception of our lives and our jobs like Murtaugh, but there is a part of us that wants to live on the edge and do things the bold way. That's the whole idea behind Shane Black's script and he sums it up well at the end. Of course it didn't hurt that he had one of the greatest directors of that decade bringing his work to life. Richard Donner is about as solid as you can get when it comes to action. While some of the scenes are definitely "please keep this locked up in the 80s" material, Donner does a lot to show you just how similar Riggs and Murtaugh are with camera angles and shots that compare them similarly.The plot is really only a vehicle for these characters to interact. It seems like every time the two go somewhere they are launched directly into an action sequence. There is no set up, no tension building; something merely explodes or suddenly there's a helicopter and a guy shooting at them. It's kind of ridiculous and the bad guys as a result seem way out in left- field, but the point is just how Murtaugh and Riggs respond to all these events and how they're changed. We just get to enjoy some great 80s gunfights along the way.

Lethal weapon is one of most iconic 80s films and my favourite baddy cop type film,all of that was achivable through great chemistry between gibson and glover duo that become one of most memorable from any franchise,this film has a lot fun captivating dialogue and humour that give us neceserey laughs betweens action setpieces and chases,villain for this type of film surved its purpose and it wasnt boring or cliched and it gave connections between him and our duo,but him could still gave more risks in his actions or bigger stakes that would have bigger impact on us,you can call this film predictable but for me that wasnt problem and i had a great time watching it

Review title: This is the classic action film that introduces one of the best action duos ever to come to the big screen.
Review_body:
Lethal Weapon is a nearly perfectly structured action movie. The acting, the story, the script, the directing, even the IDEA of the movie all combine to make up a fascinating and thrill-packed police film. The cross-cutting at the beginning of the film was particularly effective, in my opinion, as Martin Riggs (Mel Gibson) and Roger Murtaugh (Danny Glover) are introduced. The startling difference between their separate lives provides for tons of fun to be had later in the movie. Roger starts his day off as the family man reluctantly celebrating his 50th birthday party with his numerous children and his loving wife in the big family house, while Riggs is shown waking up naked in his trashy trailer and beginning his day with a healthy breakfast of a cigarette and a beer. The fact that both Roger and Riggs hated that they had to work together was especially effective in creating a touching atmosphere as they grew to be closer and closer friends. They worked so well together in this movie; it was a symbiotic relationship. It was almost like they fed off of each other, and kept each other in line and out of trouble. I also liked the way that they showed that Riggs was deeply angered when he learned that the bad guys had taken Murtaugh's daughter. Things like this, when done right, can really get you to sit up and really get into the movie, and it was definitely done right here. Riggs was also very amusing in his anxiousness about being a cop (`Why don't you let me go to sleep?' `No, come on, we gotta get up and catch bad guys!'), and Gary Busey delivers an excellent performance as the lead bad guy. This is the type of role that he plays best (see "Under Siege").
Although the violence was painfully present in some parts (the torture scenes were short but extremely difficult to watch), the film never relied on violence to pull it along or keep the audience's attention. The story was sufficient enough so that there was no overindulgence necessary in anything like that. In this film you see the first of the now traditional Lethal Weapon scenes in which Riggs and Murtaugh stagger away from a smoking crime scene, seeming to hold each other up. The final fight scene between Riggs and Mr. Joshua (Busey) was a little excessive, and there were a few scenes which were a bit faulty (how did the guy on the building ledge expect to kill himself when there was such a huge air bag inflated on the ground directly below him?), but overall this was a spectacular crime thriller. The movie rushes along at a feverish pace, and particularly Gibson's and Glover's success working together on screen make this a timeless action film that is not to be missed.

Review title: High calibre action, that's lethally addictive
Review_body: If you ever saw the movie trailer, rip roaring with action, that will appease the hardcore viewer, you won't be disappointed by what unfolds before your your very eyes in this 110 minute high level actioner, that pits probably the best two partner cops, ever seen on film, even though the two, strangers at first, take an instant disapproval to one another. Gibson, as Riggs, gives one of his best acting performances ever. He's everything the part calls for. He's a border line psycho cop/ex Vietnam vet, who needs a stable cop, like Murtaugh (Danny Glover) to take him under his wing. Riggs is a very lonely guy, who just can't get over his wife's (Victoria Lynn) death, so basically he hates the world. This latest case which becomes personal for both cops, sees a young girl suiciding by free falling several stories, plummeting to her death, where later, it's discovered she was murdered, due to cooking up, where this pretty lass, was also used in pornographic films. But there's much more to this exciting story, where the bad guys are bad, and beautifully played by two heavyweights, but I won't disclose names. Action comes thick and fast in this, with no time to really stop. What makes Lethal Weapon, better than many of it's competitor action films, is beside the explosive action, is the family angle, where in between fighting baddies, Riggs and Murtaugh, spend some time out scenes like at Murtaugh's house, when he's invited for dinner. This is a great scene, and after on Murtaughs boat, where the last scene when all the dust has settled, just upon Christmas, and Murtaughs invites Riggs in, it couldn't be penned more better. This I will say, now, is the best buddy cop partnership in history, where we are thankful for the three sequels that followed. Lethal Weapon has a great young breakthrough writer as in Shane Black who was only 23 when he wrote this. The opening of the Jingle Bell Rock song, is unexpected, and too the title song is explosive. It's so much fun here, watching mad Mel, displaying so many emotions, some moments, really scaring us, as this is one unstable dude. The woman psychiatrist, played by a late actress, is really taking the p..s out of psychiatrists generally, by her un layman terms of evaluation. One special non stop actioner, I demand you all see, which will always live with me, as the actioner of 87 that stood out when first viewing it, but too, we could do with a few more action films, not involving drug.

Mel Gibson, Danny Glover, Tom Atkins, Gary Busey, Mitch Ryan, Darlene Love, Jackie Swanson and Traci Wolfe star in Richard Donner's 1987 action film. This takes place in L.A. where we meet veteran cop, Roger Murtaugh (Glover) who has a wife, Trish (Love) and 3 kids. Roger celebrates his 50th birthday and soon gets paired up with new partner, Martin Riggs (Gibson) who has a death wish due to the loss of his late wife. Together, they investigate a murder-suicide of a young girl, Amanda Hunsaker (Swanson). Along the way, Murtaugh and Riggs get to know each other and eventually become friends. Atkins (The Fog, Halloween III) plays Amanda's wealthy father, Michael who is also Murtaugh's old friend, Busey plays drug-dealer, Joshua who works for General, Peter McCallister (Ryan) and Wolfe plays Roger's daughter, Rhianne. Gibson and Glover are great in this and together and who can forget Michael Kamen's excellent score. I recommend this great 80's action film that's definitely the best in the series.

Review title: The beginning of a beautiful friendship
Review_body: This is one of the buddy cops films I liked very much. "Lethal Weapon" is a name in the making, and I think this movie will stick in the minds of movie goers for all ages. Here you have Riggs(Mel Gibson), a neurotic cop who teams with Murtaugh(Danny Glover) a veteran family man cop. Pairs like these, you'll need someone from I.A.(Internal Affairs) to keep tabs to. I liked the Christmas tree crackdown where Riggs showed his crazy side to the crooks using the Curly maneuver, N'YUK! N'YUK!N'YUK! That's homage to the Three Stooges. When it comes to villains, Gary Busey played it well. Targeting both men, this soldier doesn't deserve an honorable mention of any sorts. The martial arts scenes were great, despite Riggs mental state, he's sane enough to protect his partner and his family, who would know that he would have eyes on Murtaugh's daughter. Hmmmmm! Other than that, this is great all the way, and these guys will be friends for life, in the films and in real life! 4 out of 5 stars.

Review title: The honest truth about one of the most beloved action/comedy series in the movie industry.
Review_body: THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS FOR ALL FOUR MOVIES!!1 - was fresh, innovative, edgy and hard. It had everything a good action movie needs to make it successful; excellent character development, imaginative direction, professional performances by the cast and crew, a clever and witty screenplay with intelligent dialog, and action...lots of good fast-paced, well-delivered action. It had a fresh comedic element without ever turning to camp or juvenile antics to solicit a chuckle from us. The comedy was educated, intelligent and expertly-delivered. The characters were lovable, and we got the feeling that we "knew" them, cared about them, wanted them to succeed. Riggs's character felt less like a character and more like a person, due to the high-level of development his character received. True, the "gun handling" left a lot to be desired, but the vast majority of audiences would not realize that you can not get 20 shots from a 16 shot clip. Nor would they realize that you can't just leave those empty clips on the ground; they cost MONEY and no CoP would do that because law enforcement officers are typically not highly paid. That aside, this was an excellent movie with wonderful entertainment value. One of the best of its kind.2 - gave us Joe Pesci's character, Leo Getz. Because of Getz, I honestly found this film to be rather endearing. Getz is one of the best characters to have been introduced to this series. Unfortunately, the edge and freshness is toned down way too much, and the action is really rather predictable. I thoroughly enjoyed bearing witness to the further development of the relationship between Riggs and Murtaugh, and was not in the least bored with that aspect. It is still a good movie, even though its edge is shelved for a more "marketable" product.3 - is just as good as 2. Riggs now has a new love interest and it seems as though all will be well and all manner of things will be well. It is still a few months away from the press release concerning the Glover/Gibson signing for 4 & 5, so it seems the series has wound down, rather than up. The action is still quality, though there are fewer and fewer unpredictable moments. The comedic aspect which was enlightened and intelligent is now a bit puerile and tired. And while the performances are still professional, it seems as though Riggs and Murtaugh both are well on their way out.4 - is the perfect ending to this series. Honestly. The characters have developed as far as I can bear to witness; Murtaugh misfires his gun in the locker room of the precinct, Riggs gets his butt kicked by a rookie cop in the boxing ring, and Riggs and Murtaugh are both just too old for this action thing anymore. (Gods help us with 60-something-year-old Harrison Ford in the upcoming "Indiana Jones 4.") Their CHARACTERS speak constantly of being too old, and I'm not talking about Murtaugh's well used line, "I'm getting too old for this sh*t." It is far beyond that. And now, with Riggs's marriage to Lorna, Murtaugh's daughter's marriage to Butters, the new babies and all the smarmy crap at the ending...enough is just enough.5 - should never happen. I don't think I can bear to see anymore smarm from these two. The characters we all loved are already gone. Like in "Invasion of the Bodysnatchers," they've been stolen from us. The edge from Riggs's character is gone. He's a bit hapless now, and sad rather than the lunatic mayhem we want and NEED from his character.The only way to pull off a 5th installment would be to kill off Lorna's character, the baby AND Butters. Either put Riggs back where his character was in 1 & 2, or don't bring him out of the moth balls. PLEASE. I loved these movies, but for the love of Mike! NO MORE!If you liked any of these movies, I highly recommend "Tango & Cash," an excellent, much-overlooked, highly under-rated "Buddy-Cop" movie.1. 9.2/102. 8.8/103. 7.6/104. 6.8/10 from...the Fiend :.

Review title: Lethal Weapon Series: Part one (and the best of the bunch).
Review_body: Lethal Weapon (1987) was the first big stateside release for Mel Gibson. After living in Australia for many moons, he returns back to his homeland with this surprise hit. Mel Gibson stars as Riggs, a loose cannon cop who lives life on the edge. He takes many chances whilst he's on duty because he doesn't care about life anymore (since the death of his wife). He's partnered with Murtaugh (Danny Glover), a nearly retired cop who's counting the days until his retirement (aren't they always going to retire in these films). Can Murtaugh keep Riggs in line? What drives Riggs to live just another day? Why is this movie filled with homo-erotic tendencies? To find out you'll just have to watch LETHAL WEAPON.This movie was the best of the bunch. I was fascinated by who cool and crazy Riggs character was. Instead of leaving it at one movie, they had to ruin the memory of the film and make three more lame action films. The longer the films went the more homo-erotic they became. I'm serious, watch these films again with this in mind.Recommended.

Yeah, yeah, yeah, I think the PC thing is that I'm not supposed to like this one but I'm supposed to like the horrible TV series instead? Something like that?Forget about it this is Shane Black at his finest macho shoot 'em up standards. And it's fun.Two cops, two Vietnam vets, two wonderfully colorful characters come together to solve a murder that grows and grows and grows until it becomes appropriately over the top and action packed fun.And, of course, by over-the-top I mean it spirals into the land of unbelievable in the way that only the finest action movies can deliver.

Review title: The model of the cop buddy genre
Review_body: With it's mix of serious thriller plot, action-comedy and chemistry between it stars Lethal Weapon has an iconic film from the 80s and as one of archetype buddy-comedy films.Danny Glover and Mel Gibson play Roger Murtaugh (Danny Glover) and Martin Riggs (Mel Gibson), two LAPD detectives who could not be more different. Murtaugh is a Sergeant who just celebrated his 50th birthday and a happy family man, whilst Riggs had just lost his wife in a car accident and has become suicidal. Both are good officers but have very different styles: Murtaugh is much more safer in his approach to Riggs as a maverick. The two are forced together after Riggs was transferred and the two are assigned to investigate the death of a prostitute. But it quickly turns out that the death was linked to a drugs ring, run by the General (Mitchell Ryan) and his loyal henchman Mr. Joseph (Gary Busey).Lethal Weapon was a film that was able to mixed a serious plot that could have worked in a thriller or police film, with strong, light-hearted relationship between Glover and Gibson. The plot is played straight and has moments of darkness, whilst the characters themselves were a bit more comic because of Murtaugh's domestic situation and Riggs' crazy personality. But this film was played to be pretty serious for the most part.Shane Black writes a very good script and with Richard Donner's direction the action is constant. Donner knew when to slow the film down to allow the characters to shine. With a good score and traditional action techniques Donner makes an exciting and fun film: but the final fight scene was a bit disappointing. Donner kept a fast pacing so it was hard to get bored with a film like this. But Lethal Weapon is Donner's best film since The Omen (I am including Superman). Black avoided clichés that plagued the genre later on, like the dressing down by the police captain or the main two characters hating each other and then becoming friends. Murtaugh and Riggs do have a chalk and cheese relationship, but they never hate each other. They learn from each other and the relationship was natural in the film's internal reality. The plot itself was as mentioned, dark and in the right level between believable but just enough to keep a level of fantasy which was needed for this type of film.The key to the film was the interaction between Glover and Gibson who worked well together. Glover was more natural and deadpan in his approach whilst Gibson was more over the time. The acting is decent for the most part.An enjoyable film.

In Los Angeles shortly before the Christmas holidays, a woman, stoned out of her mind, plummets from an apartment building and lands on a car. Two detectives get assigned to the case. One of them is a suicidal loner with a death wish; his name is Martin Riggs (Mel Gibson), still grieving over the death of his wife. The other is a family man who just turned 50; his name is Roger Murtaugh (Danny Glover). They don't like each other and that's made clear since Murtaugh knows being partnered with a psycho cop is likely to get him killed. This is the world of "Lethal Weapon," the brain-child of a trifecta of competent filmmakers: director Richard Donner, producer Joel Silver, and screenwriter Shane Black. One thing is made clear that "Lethal Weapon" takes no prisoners and is all about action, and the relationship between two guys who don't like each other but if they're to survive what they are up against, they'll need one another's help. The dead woman happens to be the daughter of an old friend of Murtaugh's (Tom Atkins), who was himself involved with mercenaries from the Vietnam War that specialized in heroin smuggling. Riggs, Murtaugh, and the man are all products of that war. Their investigation eventually leads back to these mercenaries and their shadowy leader General McAllister (Mitch Ryan) and his peroxide-blonde chief henchman Mr. Joshua (Gary Busey). What it all leads up to is a no-holds-barred showdown in one of the most action-packed finales I've ever seen. "Lethal Weapon" was of course followed by three sequels, each one less dark in tone but with more emphasis on blockbuster action, and are indeed an essential for any true action fan's library. The first "Lethal Weapon" is as tense as they come. It's fast, it's thrilling, and it's lethal.10/10

Sharp buddy cop thriller that started the great pairing of Gibson and Glover with director Richard Donner. In their first film together, Riggs and Murtaugh take on each other and a Special Forces Group from the Vietnam war that deals in drugs and murder. Explosive action; sharp dialogue and a great sense of humor start off this series with a sure fire bang.

Review title: Gibson and Glover's First Rodeo is More Than Just a Brainless Action Flick
Review_body: Mel Gibson and Danny Glover ignite a franchise with this dense, multi-faceted action flick from the mid-'80s. Although in later installments the duo grew too chummy and formulaic for my taste, Gibson and Glover's relationship in this introductory adventure is icy, complex and quite interesting, especially with the enhanced benefits of retrospect. Gibson, in his mainstream American breakthrough, is particularly good as unhinged, suicidal cop Martin Riggs, who always seems to have a pit of emotion raging behind his wide, unsettling gaze. Of course, it's an action movie from right in the heart of the genre's heyday, so there's no shortage of fireballs, gunshots, abandoned warehouses or furiously flying fists, but its big heart, strong core relationship and generally-grounded approach to the big fight scenes keep it from feeling overly indulgent. Surprisingly gripping and diverse, it's a feather in the cap for both the headline duo and their veteran director, Richard Donner.

Review title: Hard As Nails 80s Action Headed By Unorthodox Gibson
Review_body: (Flash Review)Family man and wild man are two cops at the opposite ends of the personality spectrum. Murtaugh has a family and kids and Riggs's wife has just died so isn't thinking straight on top of it all. They are thrust into breaking up a drug smuggling operation. During that, things get personal for Murtaugh as he ups the stakes. Watch the two partners battle through the dangerous case. There are some crazy action scenes, amusing banter and Gary Busey plays a strange bad guy as one would hope. I can sort of see how this sparked a movies series but at the same time, this was not as good as I remembered back in the late 80's.

Plot; A calm, rational veteran detective is paired with an unorthodox and mentally unstable younger partner.Perhaps the definitive film in the buddy cop genre, this first of four Lethal Weapon films is much darker than its sequels. Where they amped up the comedy and softened the harder edges of Mel Gibson's Martin Riggs character, the original is an occasionally brooding and jarringly violent action/dramedy.Stars Mel Gibson and Danny Glover share an incredible and effortless chemistry, and though it boasts a tight script (by Shane Black) and steady direction (by Richard Donner), it's Gibson and Glover who really make it work.

One of the best buddy cop films ever. Some of Mel Gibson and Danny Glover's best work. Sure, there are plot holes, like almost any action movie or cop movie, such as not much in the way of investigations or suspensions after police-involved shootings. But it was fast-paced, exciting, and charming in parts. Oh, yes, and this was probably Gary Busey's best work ever. Shout-out to the lovely Traci Wolfe, playing a teenager when she was much older. Unfortunately Hollywood had to make a franchise out of it. The second film was quite good, the third was OK, and I haven't bothered to see the fourth. Must see, if you're young enough to have never seen it.

Review title: Fairly enjoyable cop buddy film mainly thanks to great chemistry between the two leads
Review_body: Lethal Weapon has a pretty abrupt start to proceedings as the opening scene shows a young woman jumping off a balcony from towards the top of a tower block and landing on a car. However, this proves to have some relevance to the plot of Lethal Weapon.Basically veteran cop Murtagh (Glover)is assigned to investigate this incident which is initially deemed to be a 'suicide'. However, an autopsy confirms that the young woman was poisoned before she jumped, therefore she was murdered before she jumped. Murtagh must try to find out who poisoned the young woman and why, but he's not alone in investigating this case and is assigned a partner Riggs (Gibson). Riggs is a suicidal, unhinged police officer who has a very different method of policing to the more 'by the book' Murtagh.The majority of the humour stems from scenes with Murtagh and Riggs as both of them have a completely different style of policing. Murtagh is more straight laced and has more of a general regard for following police procedure. Whereas Riggs is unorthodox and wild and will go to more extreme methods (as you'll see in the scene where he's on the roof with a potential suicide victim). The character development is also good. Riggs in particular is afforded some depth - we learn that his wife of 11 years was killed in a car accident which explains his suicidal tendencies - it perhaps also helps to explain his rather 'gung ho' approach to policing (as he already feels suicidal, he probably doesn't fear death as much as your average police officer). We also see Murtagh's home life and see that he is a real family man. Both men show their human side, but also show that they can kick a lot of ass when necessary.There were a couple of problems with Lethal Weapon; Firstly, the final scene where Riggs is left to fight Joshua (Busey) outside Murtagh's house and no police officers bother to intercept until Riggs finally manages to get the better of him. Whilst it was dramatic and a reasonably good finale, it wasn't entirely believable. Secondly; I also felt that at times the film was a bit drawn out and it was disappointing that the baddies were given a lot less screen time than I would have hoped for.That being said, Lethal Weapon is still a good film but this is mainly due to the great on screen chemistry between Gibson and Glover. Worth watching!

Review title: An exciting cop drama cleverly constructed...
Review_body: The film opens with a panoramic aerial shot of Los Angeles, where a beautiful blonde girl in a penthouse apartment is lying, in a sexy white satin nightgown, on a luxurious red sofa... Drugs comes into focus on a table next to her... She rouses herself to sniff some white powder, steps out (completely unbalanced) onto the balcony and stands on the railing, ready to plunge peacefully down... Mel Gibson is remarkable as Martin Riggs... He is talented as both a cop and a clown... His character carries a great level of tension... He is both charismatic and enigmatic... Riggs is a homicide detective suffering harmful levels of stress, after losing his wife in an automobile accident... He seems unstable... He slaps and pummels a drug dealer in the manner of the "Three Stooges," and dares his hostage taker to shoot him...He is on the brink of despair... He takes out a bullet, loads it in his .9 millimeter Beretta, puts the gun into his mouth, and appears ready to pull the trigger...He is suicidal... He snaps a handcuff on a jumper's wrist, and snaps the other end onto his own wrist... Then he holds up the key to the cuffs, and flings it out into space...He is a sharpshooter... He raises his gun and fires without blinking, and claims that killing is "the only thing he could ever do well."He is partnered with a black middle-aged police detective to investigate the death of the girl that leaped off the balcony... Both quickly build up a strong friendship that lead them to uncover a very dangerous heroin ring...Danny Glover is at his best against an actor who can easily steal scenes... He plays an old-fashioned detective who is obsessed about his age, and goes by the book... We simply see him scanning, reading the odds...Murtaugh - on his 50th birthday - wears his past like a scar... He is a conservative family man who has to follow Riggs' hurtful plan to get his daughter back... Gary Busey plays Mr. Joshua, a trained expert killer, cool as ice, deadly calm... It's essential for him to find out how much the police know... He tries his best to get Riggs out of the picture... His boss the General (Mitch Ryan) is a rugged man with eyes like chips of stone... The ruthless general thinks that it's now the precise time to turn up the heat... He wants Murtaugh to be tortured... He kidnaps Murtaugh's little girl, the gorgeous Rianne (Traci Wolfe) to make him speak...Richard Donner's 'Lethal Weapon' is one of the finest films to offer its audience the combination of strong acting, and scenes out of hell... It is an exciting cop drama cleverly constructed... The final battle, where the two cops team up against the general and his henchmen, is especially thrilling... Donner's film also skates around the sexual implications of male bonding, but the scene in which Gibson and Glover are captured by the crooks and tortured dramatizes male vulnerability in a manner that became familiar in the action film...

With Christmas a-comin' in a couple of moths, there's no better time to rewatch the buddy cop film to end all buddy cop films. Few action movies before or since have wowed me as much as Lethal Weapon, and for good reason.Let's start with the obvious. The cast. Specifically, those two phenomenal central characters. Martin Riggs and Roger Murtaugh. Played to perfection by Mel Gibson and Danny Glover. I just love how well their respective storylines intertwined with each other. The film's central theme is family, and we get two vastly different perspectives on it. Roger the stereotypical family man, Riggs the manic-depressive-suicidal-cop-who-just-lost-his-wife.... yeah, this isn't Rush Hour. There's a lovely maturity to this film, and Martin's arc in this film was surprisingly effective, even on the rewatch. Gibson's range certainly helps sell his arc, and it helps that Glover's just as talented, playing off of Mel's manic energy amazingly well. For a movie that opens as bleak as this one does, by the end it's all smiles. The rest of the cast is fantastic too, Gary Busey especially.Behind the camera, we have Richard Donner, bringing his dependable craftsmanship to steer this project into the well-chiseled masterpiece we all know it as today.Unlike most modern films of this type, he usually holds back on the editing and more "interesting" camera angles, instead opting for a more rugged approach which really helps us be with the characters. We feel what they feel. His approach to the action sadly isn't as impressive (although he definitely gets better as the sequels go on, ending with some phenomenal set-pieces in LW4 that rank amongst the best of 90's action cinema), yet it's serviceable. This is one of the rare action films that puts character front and centre, so the action in the movie is still functional. It also helps that apart from an explosion here or there, it's mostly small and self-contained, so the geography isn't too convoluted.Michael Kamen's score is one of my favourites. I just love the soundscape he, Clapton and Sanborn created for this film (and franchise). It's funky, charming and sincere, but can also be gripping or heart-wrenching, should the need arise. Film music rarely gets better, and I wish people would bring back saxophone scores to the mainstream. I love me some good RCP action music, but listen to 'Beverly Hills Bust' and tell me you don't miss the 80s.One can't mention Lethal Weapon without, of course, mentioning Shane Black. His first produced screenplay. Unbelievable. Both Donner and Kamen said they probably wouldn't have signed on for the film had it not been for just how brilliant Black's script was. Every element of this film speaks to the core partnership between Riggs and Murtaugh, but that starts from the page. Roger only really begins to tolerate Martin around the 40 minute mark. Until then they're at each other's throats. By the end, however, it's like they're the oldest of pals, and it doesn't feel forced at all. While a lot of that credit should go to Donner, Glover, and Gibson, it's Black's phenomenal screenplay that's embedded in this relationship. His witty dialogue also helps everything feel just a tad lighter than one would expect, no matter how dark the film can sometimes go. Jeffrey Boam's contributions should also be noted, as he helped maintain that delicate tonal balance, injecting some much needed humour.I could go on and on about this film, but I won't. I've probably gone on for too long already, if I'm honest. All I can say is that Lethal Weapon is a fantastic film, one that's fit for all seasons.
Oh, this is artwork. This is goddamn artwork.

Review title: Worth a re-watch...except maybe for Mel's hair
Review_body: I caught this on TV the other night and had a blast watching it again. I had forgotten what a great movie this is and really enjoyed myself. It's aged pretty well too except maybe for the annoying score of saxophone music and possibly Mel's cool hair. Well there is that scene with the giant portable phone.Anyways, this is how buddy-cop movies are meant to be; great chemistry between our leads, humorous, without feeling forced, yet also dark and gritty with action scenes that didn't feel like they were just there for the sake of a cool stunt. This also managed to stay away from clichés and the prevalent 80's cheese factor and felt original all the way through. Just a great ride.I was also impressed with how tortured Mel's character 'Martin' is. You genuinely feel his loneliness and pain especially the scene at Christmas with his wife's photo and the hollow point bullet. On a lighter note his original hairstyle gets billing as "created by Ramsey" in the credits which made me laugh. 07.13 (3)

Review title: An Absolute Classic Cop Movie That I Grew Up Watching & Loving & A Buddy Cop Masterpiece.
Review_body:
Lethal weapon (1987) is a cop classic it's an action film & a cop Thriller & is one of the best movies of the 80's & a true classic movie!!!None of the franchise can beat part one in my opinion but part 2 is excellent also but the first movie is such a great cop film & so rewatchable & memorable.Also i loved the actress Mary Ellen Trainor as LAPD
Psychiatrist Stephanie Woods, she's always good in every film she's in & let me tell you that she has one excellent Filmography & has Starred in many Classic's like The Goonies, The Monster Squad, Ghostbusters 2, Death Becomes Her, Lethal Weapon franchise, Die Hard, Tales from the Crypt series & so much more & i just love seeing her pop up in great movies that i grew up watching. So sad she's passed away R. I. P but she lives on in these Classic films.When i was i was growing up in the 90's the Lethal Weapon films, well 1, 2 & 3 were Huge movies to nearly everyone i knew!!! My big bro had them on video & we continually watched them all the time & all my friends owned them on video & we all talked about these Classic Cop flicks & we just loved them so much & still do.Another great part of this Classic movie was the casting of the legendary Tom Atkins as Michael Hunsaker, a memorable character & role & a great performance from Atkins.I grew up watching the lethal weapon films & love the franchise & parts 1 & 2 was always my best but the first film wins hands down!!!The start is Fantastic & puts this in "Christmas film" territory like Die Hard & Die Hard 2.No need to talk about the plot or story as everyone knows it.Lethal weapon is an action packed cop CLASSIC with some amazing fight scenes & shoot outs & also features on of my favourite actor's the cool & rugged TOM ATKINS!!! So yeah everything about Lethal weapon is excellent from the cast to the look of LA & especially the night time scenes in downtown LA they look stunning & the classic jazz music score is great & fills me with Nostalgia when i hear it as this was a big film to me growing up!!!Richard Donner (R. I. P) is a legendary movie director & one of the greatest of Cinema History in my opinion.We won't ever get movies made like this again, Lethal Weapon is a perfect product of it's time & even that beautiful jazzy-score is iconic to this Classic franchise.Mel Gibson & Danny Glover have perfect chemistry in this film & both give BRILLIANT emotional & very very powerful performances!!! Not what you would normally get with an action cop film.A very special film to me & a true 80's CLASSIC that's crafted to be a thrilling piece of filmmaking by the great Richard Donner that brings out a powerful performance from Mel Gibson as troubled Martin Riggs & such a fantastic family man performance from Danny Glover as Roger Murtaugh & a whole cast of greats because of this movie such as Gary Busey for example.Lethal Weapon is timeless Classic that makes me feel Nostalgic & a sense of comfort with every viewing especially with today's mega budget CGI obsessed Superhero movie takeover.One of my all time favourite films.Gimme Lethal Weapon anytime over today's films.

Review title: One of the best action-thrillers of the 80's.
Review_body: When a young woman, who committed suicide. Which she jumped from her high-rise building. When a police detective by the name of Roger Mirtaugh (Danny Glover) finds out that the victim has a father (Tom Atkins), he knew from his Vietnam days. But Roger finds out that the victim was drugged and poisoned, which she's was going to die anyway. Since Roger's is on the cast but he's forced to team with an suicidal cop (Oscar-Winner:Mel Gibson) on the edge. Which the partners begins an unlikely friendship. When sadistic bad guys (Gary Busey and Mitchell Ryan), who are involved with the victim's death doesn't want the lead detective in their way.Directed by Richard Donner (The Goonies, Ladyhawke, Radio Flyer) made an outstanding action-thriller with sharp performances by Gibson and Glover makes this familiar if somewhat original film works.The original DVD has an fine anamorphic Widescreen (1.75:1) transfer (also in Pan & Scan) with an good digitally remastered-Dolby Digital 5.1 Surround Sound. Fans of the action genre will have a great time with this one. Director's Cut runs 117 minutes. Written by Shane Black (Kiss Kiss Bang Bang, The Last Boy Scout, The Long Kiss Goodnight). (****/*****).
I heard it was great, but all I noticed was the generic storyline and not much or interesing action. I could notice the great characters, but that's about it.

One of the best action movies of the 80's. One of the best cop buddy movies ever,, you got Glover, Gibson, Murtaugh,, Riggs,, one just had a birthday,, the other psycho, maybe suicidal, perfect match,, then you got one of the greatest bad guys of the past say 20 years,, Gary Busey,, he plays the part of Joshua. basically the cops have to try and stop a shipment of Heroin before it get's to the docks. Riggs just lost his wife,, but they don't go into any kind of detail how it really happened and all,, he lives alone,, with his dog,, kinda looks like Lassie,, on a trailer on the beach.. Murtaugh is married big family,, even has a boat.. There is lots of action in this one,, but the best thing is that it is so darn funny, the one - liners they give these boys is just unrealistic,, i think this is def. in my top 250 i don't know how IMDb will look at it,, but definitely a winner in my book

Richard Donner's fast-paced action film was one of the best from the 1980's. Detectives Murtaugh (Danny Glover) and "Lethal Weapon" Riggs (Mel Gibson) are on the trail of drug lords who will stop at nothing to keep their operation functional. The story from Shane Black makes for an over the top movie, yet it is restrained enough to be enjoyable. And Donner makes sure the two leads are portrayed as real people that we can relate to.The end does take proceedings a little too far, but does not spoil the roller coaster ride which Gibson and Glover seem to have enjoyed as much as the audience will. Also starred Gary Busey and Mitch Ryan.Thursday, August 13, 1992 - Video

'Lethal Weapon' is a movie that knows what it is to be a buddy movie and a hard police movie at the same time. Comedy and action come together in the perfect way. In a way it is your typical buddy movie. An older and wiser black cop and a younger white cop, living on the edge, team up. The black cop is personally involved in the case they handle, the white cop is a little suicidal.Where most movies like this work to hard on the relationship between the two and therefore force most of the jokes, 'Lethal Weapon' starts by being a good action movie and from there it thinks further. The movie is funny because the characters simply do what you would expect them to do and because personalities collide it gets funny. Not that it is very different in other movies like this, but in those movies the characters have some strange habits to make it funny. Here the characters feel more real.The black cop is Roger Murtaugh (Danny Glover), the white cop Martin Riggs (Mel Gibson). Together they have to solve a case that involves drugs, an old Vietnam friend of Murtaugh and a villain played by Gary Busey. The screenplay is not very complicated, more like a simple police story, but it has some nice touches. We know Gibson can not die in the first couple of minutes of the movie, but when he holds that gun to his own head we really feel the fear he must have. This movie is one of the reasons he is the star he is today, and you understand why. Glover is nice as well, and that he and Gibson, together with director Richard Donner, made three other Lethal Weapon' movies together is no surprise. They are one of the best teams I have seen, for the action and for the comedy.

It's over 30 years since watched Lethal Weapon and I thought it was about time I revisited Riggs and Murtaugh to see how time has treated them and sure , it does look a little dated but the film is still a lot of fun .Mel Gibson and Danny Glover were big stars back in 1987 . Glover had just been in The Color Purple and Gibson has just finished his third Mad Max movie so it made total sense to put the two together for this film and they undoubtedly worked really well together but Gibson was by no means first choice for the role .
Just take a look at the list of actors who were considered or turned down the role of Riggs .Alec Baldwin, Jeff Bridges, Pierce Brosnan, Bryan Brown, Nicolas Cage, Robert De Niro Kevin Costner, Willem Dafoe, Michael Douglas, Harrison Ford, Richard Gere, Jeff Goldblum, Rutger Hauer, Don Johnson, Michael Keaton, Kevin Kline, Christopher Lambert, Michael Madsen, Liam Neeson, Michael Nouri, Al Pacino, Sean Penn, William Petersen, Dennis Quaid, Christopher Reeve, Eric Roberts, Kurt Russell, Arnold Schwarzenegger, Tom Selleck, Charlie Sheen, Sylvester Stallone, Patrick Swayze, John Travolta and Bruce Willis .That has to be the most turned down roll in movie history and you just can't imagine any of the above being Riggs so it all turned out well in the end .The film is by no means perfect , in fact the story is pretty lame but the two leads along with one of the 1980's best baddie actors , Gary Busey , make the film a great piece of escapism .

Mel Gibson is Martin Riggs an out of control loose cannon cop who lost his wife of 11-years. As he is struggling to survive as he is suffering burn out. And that nobody in the department wants him as he is been tagged as a "Lethal Weapon!"Danny Glover is the perfect straight man to Gibson's recklessness as Roger Murtaugh on the verge of retirement and is more of the by the book and rules follower compared to Gibson's reckless cop ways.But despite the two getting on one another's nerves. As their success rate in getting closed cases. But also their friendship as both need each other to lean on. Off and on the force.Director Richard Donner does a great job in the franchise. As the movies are really show the friendship and partnership of two cops who lean on one another.

Review title: More entertaining than, but almost as dated as me
Review_body: I'll have to be careful what I put for the first Lethal Weapon; it's one of my daughter's favourite films and when younger she used to have a crush on Mel Gibson. So, it was a marvellous, even classic film.But what of the flimsy plot? Black and white cops up against ex-army heroin smugglers, interspersed by shedloads of comedy. How about the slapstick acting caricaturing the police force of the time, to be sure an ancient time when officers went about shouting Yipikaye to the baddies as they killed them unmercifully. The schmaltzy family scenes in contrast to the vigilante attitudes? No matter how laughable this always was or how dated it's getting it was always prime entertainment and a great way to spend two hours. Like Die Hard it was a deliberate and laudable propaganda attempt to get black and white people to understand together and to work for their common good together. Like Die Hard it had Christmas violence and baddies beyond the pale, in fact albino – baddies who only deserved to be terminated.It portrayed a brilliant fantasy world where Health & Safety or police protocols played no part, along with mobile phones, the internet and without the cgi cartoonery that's taken over movies in the last 20 years. There seemed to be plenty of time to enjoy nonsensical action films such as this back then. But I loved it again tonight and am already looking forward to the next time to check how much more dated it will have become.

Lethal Weapon is an incredible action comedy with two incredible performances from Mel Gibson and Danny Glover, who have fantastic chemistry. Richard Donner's direction is great, resulting in really enjoyable and well filmed action sequences. Shane Black's scripts is fantastic and consistently really funny. It's also well paced with really good music by Michael Kamen and Eric Clapton.

Review title: Lethal Weapon is a buddy cop film par excellence
Review_body: With visceral, breathtaking action sequences and a shockingly good performance from Aussie bred Mel Gibson, Lethal Weapon stands as possibly the greatest buddy cop film ever made. After three star making performances in the Mad Max movies, Gibson (as suicidal cop Martin Riggs) built a whole new character niche for himself here. He is paired with the perfectly cast Danny Glover (L.A.P.D. Sergeant Roger Murtaugh) and the two of them become involved in taking down a ruthless drug dealer/murderer of the daughter of one of Murtaugh's closest friends.The very popular Lethal Weapon franchise went on to produce three more sequels. The fact that the first one stays away from the comedic element (this was overdone on the next 3 installments), makes it more atmospheric, more tension-filled, and vehemently more effective. Watch out for Gary Busey (a.k.a. Joshua) as a side villain who's pure, nasty fun. Richard Donner of The Goonies and Superman fame directs at a fast, workmanlike clip.

Review title: An entertaining buddy cop action film
Review_body: Buddy Cop films were not uncommon in the 80s for several reasons. A big reason was that they permitted heavy violence with comical one liners. Another reason though was to pair up two odd ball actors together in one movie. It was a big grab because it allowed for audiences to see interactions between stars that were not normally seen in other genres. Among all the productions that were made, the most popular and critically praised was Richard Donner's Lethal Weapon (1987), the director best known for Superman (1978) and The Goonies (1985) up to that point. Then, attach writer Shane Black to the production and it became an instant hit. Shane Black is the more successful brother of Terry Black, the writer behind Dead Heat (1988).Black's set up to the main story is for the most part like any other buddy cop film. Roger Murtaugh (Danny Glover) is an older police officer on the force getting close to retirement. Officer Martin Riggs (Mel Gibson) is widower who can't be handled by his coworkers. Ever since he lost his wife, Riggs has been on the edge and no one wants to be partnered up with him. That is until he gets assigned to be with Murtaugh. Once Riggs meets Murtaugh, there is initial friction but they soon grow on each other with emotional backstories that are developed enough for the audience to care and understand. Aside from that, both Glover and Gibson give their characters a decent dose of charm. Glover is great at being the tired elderly cop and Gibson is great at being all over the place and bouncing off the walls. These contrasts are fun especially when they share the screen together.There's also a number of supporting actors cast in this movie. Gary Busey and Tom Atkins also have significant roles to play. Tom Atkins plays key a part in a homicide that Riggs and Murtaugh have to figure out. Gary Busey doesn't play a unique individual but makes his performance interesting because he's not all out crazy. He's a bit disturbing but not loony. That's Gibson's role anyway. Sadly there isn't much to say about cinematography or editing. It is competently done though. The cinematographer was Stephen Goldblatt (who might be editor Mark Goldblatt's brother?). The editor was Stuart Baird, who also worked with Donner on Superman (1978). Other than that, there's nothing to say that really stood out. The action was handled well especially when it came to fight sequences. Mel Gibson sure knew how to throw a punch. As for shootings and car chases, nothing there felt special either, I actually expected more. Musically related, Michael Kamen produced the score while collaborating with Eric Clapton. Was it memorable? Ehh,...no not really. However, the sound was different than most scores. This particular score highlighted the most saxophone in it than any other score I've listened too. This made it unique, sadly not enough to remember though. I don't even recall a main theme. However, there were some scenes that were effective - like Mel Gibson's emotional trauma. That worked, but it worked on occasion. It is still a well-made action film no doubt.It has a good cast of actors, fun action and a well-written story. Music and camera-work are good too but nothing to be amazed over. Fun fun.

Although I wasn't a big fan when these films came out, later I came to appreciate them. Especially the original, as is typically the case. It is a brilliant film: Funny, with non-stop action and a good plot. This was pulled off by an excellent director (RIchard Donner) and both of the lead actors. As a rule, I dislike sequels, and this is no exception. I remember when "Death Wish" (1974) with Charles Bronson came out. For me, it was the first of the revenge films, along with the "2,3,4" sequel syndrome. Both of these formulas have been beaten into the ground. The sequel part has occurred in every genre of film one can think of. Perhaps the most exploitative are the "Fast & Furious" movies. Of course "Star Wars" is up there as well, although that has a much different type of fan base. Regardless, this is the best when it comes to "cop/buddy" films. If I recall, it was the highest grossing film that year; if not, it was way up there. A must see.

One of the quintessential 80's action/cop/buddy cop movies. Glover and Gibson make a good pairing, the conflict is ratcheted up nicely, and Donner's direction give an epic feel to the action sequences. What the movie does, it does well.The plot involves an investigation into the death of a young woman, Amanda Hunsaker (Jackie Swanson), the daughter of an old war buddy of Murtaugh's, Michael Hunsaker (Tom Atkins), who is now a successful banker. Ultimately, it leads Riggs and Murtaugh into some murky waters where they encounter a former General, Peter McAllister (Mitchell Ryan), and some ex-special forces mercenaries, including the especially psychotic Mr. Joshua (Gary Busey). There's some twists and turns along the way, but most importantly Donner keeps the action going and the tension building all the way to the climax. The dialogue is sharp, the story and characters are developed extremely well, and Donner wisely injects some humorous moments (courtesy of Gibson, with shades of The Three Stooges) that provide a respite to the intensity of the overall proceedings. But what really makes this movie is the pairing of Gibson and Glover. Perfectly cast as Riggs, Gibson is at his charismatic best here. He brings a depth to his character usually reserved for more dramatic fare, and layers him with a complexity that makes Riggs so much more than just another action hero. If you look deeply enough, you'll find a bit of McQueen's "Bullitt" in him.Along the way, however, an interesting thing happens. We are teated to actual characters, not typical shallow action-types. Riggs is shown to be a grieving widower, trying to make sense of things, while Murtaugh is a straight-laced family man who has to confront the baddies when they kidnap his daughter. They sort out their perspectives along the way, which is just as much a part of the story as the shoot-em-up action. It is no wonder, that these guys made several "Lethal Weapon" movies. They genuinely seemed to have a good time making this film.Overall rating: 9 out of 10.

.The opening scene starts with an airborne view of Los Angeles where a gorgeous blonde chick, clad in a white nightgown,lying on a red sofa. Next to her on a table with drugs situated on top. The young lady gets up to sniff the drugs, then walks outside to the balcony, leans toward the railing and take her fatal plunge to her death.Mel Gibson was flat-out excellent as mentally unbalanced cop Det. Martin Riggs. As he combines his versatility as both a strong action hero and a lovable clown. Using both his charm and charisma, Riggs is probably one of the most endearing characters in film history. As a man who's perpetually grief-stricken after the death of his wife in a fatal automobile accident, Riggs has been living an unsettling life. Hell go far as to dare someone dangerous to kill him, even if its just for kicks. Many times Riggs tries to kill himself. With the assistance of his .9 mm. Beretta, he places the gun into his mouth and attempts to pull the trigger. Other attempts of suicidal tendencies is when another hes on top of a building and another jumper is nearby. He places one part of a handcuff on the jumpers wrist and another on his wrist as he gracefully throws the key in the air. As a unstable gunman, he fires shots without blinking claiming that "killing was the only thing he could do well".Riggs joins forcing with a reluctant ageing African-American police detective Roger Murtaugh (Danny Glover) to explore further investigation to the suicide of the young lady who fell to her death, which puts the dynamic duo in the centre of a major drug bust. Glover is equally effective and is known for stealing every scene he's in. Murtaugh is from the old-school of investigating as he is fixated on retirement but prefers to play by the rules rather than take risks like his partner Riggs. Pushing towards 50, Murtaugh wants to just forget about his achievements he's accomplished as an investigator and wants to spend time with his family.When news gets around that his daughter has been kidnapped, Murtaugh bites his tongue and goes along with Riggs risky ways in order to get his daughter back. Gary Busey is Mr. Joshua,a cold-blooded evil drug-lord who's also has had experience as a Vietnam vet. Joshua will go to any lengths necessary into how much the cops know about his drug rings. His boss General Peter MacAllister (Mitchell Ryan) who looks even more menacing than Joshua like as though he has icicles running through his veins. The evil general turns up the crank in the investigation by ordering Murtaugh to be annihilated and in the process kidnaps his adorable daughter Rianne (Traci Wolfe) in order for Murtaugh to speak. Director Richard Donner this movie combines plenty of bone-chilling action, great humour and brilliant acting by the cast. This goes beyond all expectancies from a cop-drama. The final action scenes pit Riggs and Murtaugh against the General and his goons features some of the best choreographed fight scenes ever put on film.

Lethal Weapon is the only film I have seen in the series.It is a cop/buddy movie starring Mel Gibson and Danny Glover.I thought it was pretty good, it had some entertaining moments(some humor as well) and it was just like any other cop/buddy movie of the 1980's.I personally think the Beverly Hills Cop movies were better(but I have only seen this one in the series).The film is about a cop who must solve one more case, he is also close to retirement.He is paired with a crazy, suicidal cop(played by Gibson in a good role) and together they must stop a gang of drug smugglers.Lethal Weapon is a fun cop/buddy movie but it's not excellent by any means.

Beginning with the first Christopher Reeves Superman movie, the creative concept guys at Warner Bros. realized that if you sank millions of dollars into a B-movie formula, including hiring the right cast and crew, you would not only get millions of dollars in return, but everybody would be talking about it like it was an A-class film. (This knowledge had already been discovered by the James Bond team, but only with the success of Star Wars and the Indiana Jones films did it at last become obvious to all.) Look, Lethal Weapon, like so many other action films since that discovery was made, is a factory product. Some committee came up with the idea and set about hiring a team to realize it. It is all surface and no substance. There's no vision here, it's all meant to make money, that's all.I enjoy this film, very much - I've seen it over and over again, and I am thrilled by the action scenes and amused by the humor. But great film-making this is NOT. It's very slick, but it's also noisy, and clunky in spots, exploitative (did we really need to see the porn film the dead girl made?), overlong (with occasionally questionable editing choices), and it's "dramatic" moments are clearly intended to manipulate rather than arouse our emotions. This isn't even remarking the lack of realism regarding police procedure or the consequences of the behavior of the two heroes. Finally, as is apt for a B-movie, all the major players ham it up something fierce.But all this is entirely forgivable once one admits that, yeah, it's just a B-movie, after all, an amusing way to spend two hours when you have nothing better to do and want to watch good guys chase bad guys and blow things up.

My parents seen these films long ago back when they were on VHS & they mentioned how good these films were so I got the boxset for Christmas & watched this one first! I'd have say after many watches, it's a pretty damn good film!The film follows 2 newly paired Police Officer who are complete opposites of one another. Riggs is a Crazy, Mad Police Officer who lost his wife & has suicidal tendencies so he doesn't care whether he lives or dies, & Murtaugh, is a soon-to-be-retired Police Officer who is more sensible & careful when it comes to his Police work. But despite their differences & barriers, the 2 must work together to catch a gang of ruthless drug smugglers.I found the film to be pretty good! It mixes action, comedy & sadness well! There's plenty of funny one liners, action packed & has a decent enough story-line! The characters of Riggs & Murtaugh are great! The banter between them is pretty good & adds to the films crazyness! Much like with Hobbs & Shaw from the Fast & Furious films, their differences & banter work well & are a staple in the 4 films! The villain Joshua, was also pretty good as well & had a good level of menace & ruthlessness about him!Overall, it's a really good action buddy-cop film of the 80's!8/10.

Review title: A fun action movie that has great characters and chemistry ( C+Movie ) My Ratings 8/10
Review_body: Arguably the greatest buddy cop film of all time, Lethal Weapon is the first of a successful franchise that is the quintessential action film of the '80s that boasts an entertaining narrative and a talented cast including terrific performances by Mel Gibson, Danny Glover and Gary Busey.

Mel Gibson and Danny Glover have a chemistry as a duo that is unsurpassed in the action genre, many action flicks have a cop duo, but there is nearly always a weak character (and sometimes there are 2) Riggs and Murtaugh, thrown together as partners, have to battle against Riggs's madness and a bunch of highly motivated and very professional drug dealers.Investigating the apparent suicide of a young woman (the daughter of Murtaugh's Viet-Nam buddy) The pair begin to form a very dangerous partnership of experience and expertise, based on necessity rather than trust. With Murtaugh's daughter kidnapped and his own life on the line, we will find out how Lethal Riggs is.A rare blend of good characters and some light comic relief, this movie has all you need for a couple of hours of high octane entertainment.9/10

Review title: The safety catch is permanently off... !
Review_body: Cop who is a 'loose cannon'... Ho hum, right? Not in this case. Mel Gibson plays the role with frightening believability (as anyone who is familiar with his recent behaviour might not be surprised to hear... ) but also with an always self-deprecating sense of humour. He's very aware of his own faults and his relation to the world around him, a personal facet of the character as written that I find consistently amusing. Shane Black is unafraid to explore the scuzzier side of police work with his writing - in fact he positively wallows in it - so we're happy to accept with these two things combined that "Lethal Weapon" isn't just a catchy title, it might actually be the truth.Although the pairing of two such types is predictable, Danny Glover is equally as good in a different way taking on the role of Riggs' straight-laced partner. The banter between the two is very sharp but always stops just short of being terminally cutting. It's a teaming that each successive sequel builds upon to advantageous effect.This instalment is definitely the grittiest of the four, as thereafter the studios and Black's replacement scribes experimented with leavening the balance between action and humour. Over time Riggs' rough edges became sanded down, but for a full demonstration of his madcap antics when he was at his crazy peak, be sure not to miss this one. Nowhere else has instability been used as the basis for such an adrenaline-fuelled ride.

Review title: THE EPITOME OF THE BUDDY-COP FLICK!
Review_body: This is one of those flicks where, if you go too long without a rewatch, you slowly start to forget just how much of a near-masterpiece it is. Or maybe I'm just getting old.Every scene is on point as all hell. The perfect combination of pulp, grit, action, suspense and drama. I'd long thought Martin Riggs was my favorite character, but who am I kidding? The saxophone is probably my favorite character in all of cinema. In fact, you know what? It is! Move over Dr. Loomis and Rain Man... There's a saxophone comin' through.My introduction to this film was via VHS bargain bin back in the day. I think Movie Gallery was doing one of their 3 for $15 sales, if I remember correctly. I usually used said sales to purchase two flicks I'd already rented and loved, then took a chance on something well-known but that had slipped under my radar for whatever reason. Out of all those dice rolls, this was undoubtedly the best chance I ever took. I'd go on to absolutely LOVE the concept of buddy-cop flicks, but unfortunately few would ever live up to this gem.Also, Tom Atkins, the greatest actor of all time, is somewhat present. What a gem of a movie.

Review title: A high-water mark in mismatched buddy cop action comedies.
