Review title: Best buddy cop movie there is
Review_body: Lethal Weapon to me is one of the best buddy cop movie that I have seen, the combination of Sgt Martin Riggs and Sgt Roger Murtaugh is one of the best character pairing when it comes to this genre and we were given the honor to see this paring done by first class actors in Mel Gibson and Danny Glover. This movie combines high tense action with humor that makes you want to see more of these guys, as it ends you just find yourself desiring that it didn't. From the very beginning this casting was set from someone high in heaven, because according to Wikipedia Casting director Marion Dougherty first casting suggestion was Mel Gibson and Danny Glover, which ended up being what we saw on screen.They were both like a diamond in a rock, one an all-round good guy with a family man consisting of 3 children and the other a widower with suicidal intentions and nothing to live for until he met the first. These were Murtaugh and Riggs respectively and if you think you can cross any of these guys and just walk away you got another thing coming.The first of the four series is this one which was released in 1987; it stands as the introduction piece of how Murtaugh and Riggs met, and how they bonded. Murtaugh (Danny Glover) at that time was 50 years of age enjoying the life of being a straight shooter cop until he got partnered with a younger suicidal cop Riggs (38 at that time) (Mel Gibson) who no one wants to work with. Now both guys who are like a mix of crazy and normal must learn to work with one another to stop a gang of drug smugglers.As easy as this may sound on paper it wasn't on screen, as we get to go through scenes after scenes of both parties ready to do what it takes to get the job done. The music score in this movie is one that you will love as it was done by Michael Kamen and Eric Clapton. The Jazz feel is just exquisite, moving ahead my favorite scene in the movie; "Spoiler Alert" is where Riggs convinced a man that was going to jump to appreciate living. He did this by making the man live up to his word when he was threatening to jump, Riggs made him jump.After this the duo went ahead to make 3 other films similar to this and they from my point of view were just as beautiful as this one was.www.lagsreviews.com

Review title: An excellent action movie that is still enjoyable today.
Review_body: Lethal Weapon makes a dynamic impact on the action buddy cop genre. Take two mismatched cops and make them reluctant partners, and as their relationship forms they go up against the bad guys and take them down. It's an 80's movie through and through, but it's still an enjoyable movie today. The best thing about Lethal Weapon is that it's not a "leave your brain at the door" action movie with gunplay, fights and explosions that ignores the story. It's not a movie with action for the sake of action, and it certainly not a movie that relies on an endless body count. The action and violence fits in perfectly with the story to make it believable as the movie flows very smoothly. Lethal Weapon makes its name as a great action movie that never stops, interesting well rounded characters, crackling and witty dialogue with occasional moments of humour, excellent cinematography, and a fully fleshed out story with excellent attention to detail.The movie starts with Jingle Bell Rock playing over the opening credits as the camera pans over the blue tinted Los Angeles skyline at night. The mood quickly changes when Amanda Hunsaker (Jackie Swanson) leaps to her death from her apartment balcony which forms the basis of the story. Sergeant Roger Murtaugh (Danny Glover) investigates the apparent suicide and he later finds out that Amanda Hunsaker is the daughter of Michael Hunsaker (Tom Atkins), a former Vietnam Veteran that Roger served with during the war. At the same time, we are introduced to Sergeant Martin Riggs (Mel Gibson), a crazy, wild eyed rebel with a death wish following the death of his wife in a car accident in 1984. Martin Riggs has lost the will to live and often takes wild risks, hoping he will die in the line of duty. Riggs and Murtaugh are polar opposites. Roger Murtaugh has just celebrated his 50th birthday and he is a proud family man at heart. He is also a conservative by-the-book police detective who is also considering retirement after 20 years with the Los Angeles Police Department. Martin Riggs is a police detective with a wild suicidal streak who is not afraid to put himself in harms way. He has attempted suicide but decides against it as he hopes to end his misery in the line of duty. Riggs has also served in the Vietnam War and was a former US Army Special Forces soldier specialising as a trained killer. These skills have served him well as well as his psychotic behaviour which gives him a dangerous edge against his enemies. Following serious concerns about Riggs' wild behaviour, he is transferred from Narcotics to Homicide and partnered with Murtaugh. Though they resent each other at first, their partnership grows solid throughout the movie, and also giving Martin Riggs a new lease on life. Amanda Hunsaker's suicide turns out not to be the case as the trail leads Riggs and Murtaugh to a heroin smuggling syndicate operated by a former Special Forces group named Shadow Company which operated during the Vietnam War. Shadow Company is made up of a gang of mercenaries led by ex-military General Peter McAllister (Mitchell Ryan) and his chief enforcer and right hand man Mr Joshua (Gary Busey). Riggs and Murtaugh take on McAllister and Mr Joshua when they declare war through the streets of Los Angeles.Besides Braveheart and Mad Max, Lethal Weapon is one of Mel Gibson's best movies. Mel Gibson's role as Martin Riggs is certainly one to remember. His character is psychotic and unstable like a powder keg waiting to explode, but he also brings a comedic side to Riggs with a love of The Three Stooges. Danny Glover is tailor made to the role of Roger Murtaugh, a sensible police detective and a proud family man at heart. Gary Busey's role as the intimidating enforcer Mr Joshua made him a great villain. Believe it or not, this was Gary Busey's first role as a villain which has seen him cast as the villain such as Under Siege (1992) and Drop Zone (1994) or a crazed character such as Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas (1998), and also lends his voice in Grand Theft Auto: Vice City (2002).Richard Donner previously directed The Omen (1976) and Superman (1978) and had cemented his reputation as a reliable director. Richard Donner created an unbeatable chemistry with Lethal Weapon and there has not been a movie that has been able to beat it. He has also since carried on with the chemistry with a further three sequels. Writer Shane Black found himself in high demand for action movies following the success of Lethal Weapon and since then, he has written The Last Boy Scout (1991) and The Long Kiss Goodnight (1996) and received a record setting sum of money for his work. He has proved he is not just a pretty face as an actor appearing as Hawkins in Predator (1987) and small roles here and there, as well as striking success as a director with Kiss Kiss Bang Bang (2005) and Iron Man 3 (2013). Producer Joel Silver also can add Lethal Weapon to his long list of box office blockbusters along with 48 Hrs (1982), Predator (1987), Die Hard (1988), The Matrix (1999), and Sherlock Holmes (2009).There have been numerous "buddy cop" movies that have been released since Lethal Weapon, and numerous movies such as but not limited to Tango & Cash (1989), The Rookie (1990), Bad Boys (1995) and its sequel Bad Boys II (2003), The Glimmer Man (1996), The Other Guys (2010), and The Heat (2013) do not hold a candle to Lethal Weapon or any of its sequels.Lethal Weapon is still an enjoyable action movie years later, and the magic continues with Riggs and Murtaugh returning in Lethal Weapon 2 (1989), Lethal Weapon 3 (1992), and Lethal Weapon 4 (1998). Definitely a must see for all fans of action movies.9/10.

Review title: A buddy action movie the way it's properly done, but in 2021 little bit dated
Review_body: Before the buddy-cop formula became overused "Lethal Weapon" was viewed to have much freshness compare to most of the late 1980s action movies. In the 33+ years since film was first released, a good bit of it may seem dated but will still be fun for those that appreciate the era. The chemistry between D. Glover and M. Gibson is readily apparent and stays that way. The plot is little bit over the top, but it's easy to forgive, because "Lethal Weapon" is one of those rare action films that has a little for everyone, even when it makes spiraling out of control.Rating: 6+/7-

It's a good movie. I watched alot as a kid and liked it very much. Now is just ok. Girl doing drugs and jumping to her death(Judge Jredd). Alot like Die Hard, but Die Hard is better. Also not as funny.
34 years and its still as enjoyable as it was back then the ultimate Good Cop Bad Cop partnership.

Review title: Funny, action packed, excellent cop movie
Review_body: Take a cop who's lost everything and is not afraid of death, pair him with a 50 year old cop, who has a family and a promising job position and has led a nice life, and you get Lethal Weapon.The pair go up against a gang of drug dealers, led by corrupt former army General Peter MacAllister (Mitch Ryan). MacAllister has a creepy second hand man, Mr. Joshua (Gary Busey), who is hell bent on his task.Luckily, Roger Murtaugh (Danny Glover) and Martin Riggs (Mel Gibson) aren't going to let them get away so easily.There are plenty of great scenes and a lot of fun action. You can not watch this without smiling.9/10

Review title: Possibly the granddaddy of "Buddy Cop" movies.
Review_body: Gibson and Glover are the greatest duo in what has to be the greatest "buddy cop" action movie ever made. Most of the action is saved for the third act so we can get some character development. But, the writing from Shane Black of "Predator" and the directing from the great Richard Donner, are excellent. Plus you have Gary Busey as our villian before he went full tilt crazy guy.

Review title: As good as LW4 was bad
Review_body: "Lethal Weapon" was as good a movie as "Lethal Weapon 4" was bad a movie -- and this is saying a lot!This movie introduced many popular (endlessly copied) story themes and film elements to Hollywood.  Much credit must go to the original Lethal Weapon. It scores a Hollywood 10.

It's all about the partnership! Both are great characters and some iconic scenes here, it does turn into very typical action shoot em up from about half way through and for me loses a little of what it starts out to be, but easy watching all the same!

This is a stupid garbage movie with a lame story, dumb, ridiculous action scenes and rage inducing out of place saxophone music.It's not some kind of "classic", people who think that have their rose-colored
nostalgia glasses on.

The cinematography was pretty good, and so were the gunfire and explosions. I'm sure there are some people who consider Mel Gibson's acting a little over the top when Martin is behaving in an unhinged manner, and Danny Glover's acting when Roger is angry, which is understandable. Personally, I don't have a problem with it. There were other moments and things that were a little over the top as well, which I don't have a problem with, either. And I really liked the development and progression of what started out as an annoyance on Roger's part towards Martin to what ended up being a unity of camaraderie between both of them by the end of the movie. Good movie.

Review title: Gibson and Glover as a dynamic duo
Review_body: Mel Gibson stars in this influential (For better or worse) buddy film as a stressed out suicidal cop who is paired up with a set to retire Danny Glover to chase down some bad guys. While paired up the two discover a drug running scheme by some ex special forces men.With plenty of action, violence, explosions, and just the right touch of humor. Lethal Weapon entertains. Gibson and Glover are great together and the presence of Eric Clapton on the soundtrack adds to it. Two sequels followed but as in most cases the first is the best. On a scale of one to ten..8

Review title: A buddy cop movie that enjoys a cast so perfect that its alchemy literally explodes on the screen
Review_body: This is the excellent idea of denouncing the crimes of the mafia and narco-traffickers of "Air America", through the evil actions of its Los Angeles unit, more than a decade after the end of the Anglo-American imperialist holocaust in Southeast Asia. In a subtle way, under the disguise of a buddy cop movie that enjoys a cast so perfect that its alchemy literally explodes on the screen! In this first episode in 1987, and then in three other installments, respectively in 1989, 1992 and 1998, to form the Lethal Weapon quadrilogy. Maybe a pentalogy, since both Mel Gibson and Danny Glover are not only interested but also seem more and more motivated by the idea of teaming up again as Martin Riggs and Roger Murtaugh on the big screen, more than 20 years after their last "lethal" encounter. They have been publicly teasing it since 2017. Screenplay (Shane Black), directing (Richard Donner), soundtrack (Michael Kamen) and editing are just as smart and effective and complete this classic movie of its generation.

Review title: One Of The Best Action Films Ever Made. An Unforgettable,Landmark Classic.
Review_body: Lethal Weapon is one of the best Action films ever made that is filled with great direction,intense Action,a great screenplay,excellent acting and a wonderful score making Lethal Weapon one of the all-time great Action movie classics,one of my favorite Action and one of my favorite films period.Set in Los Angeles,CA,Lethal Weapon tells the story of veteran L.A.P.D cop Roger Murtaugh(Danny Glover)who now has to team with suicidal cop Martin Riggs(Mel Gibson)to investigate a homicide while going after a drug cartel. Riggs and Murtaugh now must figure out how to work together and solve the case while at the same time try to get to know one another and figure each other out and Murtaugh get used to Riggs as a Lethal Weapon.Lethal Weapon is one of those Action movie classics that made me fall in love with the Action genre and gave viewers an introduction to one of the greatest film screen duos of all time Riggs and Murtaugh and a masterful introduction to the amazing Lethal Weapon series. Right from the opening credits to the end you are glued to the screen because of the Action,thrills,suspense and memorable characters in the film. I think that one of the reasons Lethal Weapon is such a brilliant film is because the film took the Buddy cop concept of the Action-Comedy Walter Hill classic 48 Hrs and flipped it and instead of being the cop and criminal this time both are cops. It's no coincidence that both Lethal Weapon and 48 Hrs were both co-produced by Joel Silver. Where as the other Lethal Weapon sequels we're light and much more comedic,LW1 is more gritty and dark because LW1 while an Action is also a great character study of Riggs and Murtaugh because the film shows that Riggs is depressed and on the verge of suicide while Murtaugh has to deal with getting older and his new partner Riggs. And while LW is a serious Action film there are moments of funny humor but the Humor is done in a cynical tone and the comedy is not as over the top as the sequels. LW in some way bridged a gap between the Action films of the 70s and 80s and the early 90s by being serious with a dark sense of Humor. That being said I love all of the LW films. The screenplay by Shane Black is brilliant and excellent,well-written and one of the best Action screenplays of all time with Black giving the main characters memorable dialog with some dark humor and giving the two main characters powerful depth. Black would continue writing brilliant Action scripts with Lethal Weapon 2,The Last Boy Scout,The Long Kiss Goodnight and Kiss,Kiss,Bang,Bang. Riggs and Murtaugh are classic characters of Action films and cinema in general. Like any great Action buddy film,Riggs and Murtaugh at first don't like each other and it's not only because the two don't want to work with one another it's also because of how opposite the two are. Riggs is more wild and filled with energy where as Murtaugh is more straight and narrow but as the film goes on Riggs and Murtaugh begin to understand and like each other. Riggs and Murtaugh feel like real characters who not stereotypes but real people that viewers can relate to. It is the difference between the characters that makes Riggs and Murtaugh so great and entertaining and the banter and dialog makes this film and the other LW films so amazing and watchable. I also love the villains in the film and despite the villains not having much screen time they are vicious and dark in the way they do things and leave a huge impression. The film moves at a great pace and never slows down once the Action kicks into high gear The Action scenes in the film are excellent and handled with intensity and white hot suspense and the Action scenes would get better and bigger as the LW films went on. The final 20-30 minutes are among the best endings that you will see in a Action film and it is so thrilling and Action packed that you will barely have time to catch your breath. It is an excellent ending that will stay in you after the film is over and will put a smile on viewers faces.The whole cast is great in their roles. Mel Gibson and Danny Glover are excellent and at their best as Martin Riggs and Roger Murtaugh,with Gibson and Glover bringing depth,intensity and great chemistry to their roles. Gary Busey(Joshua) and Mitchell Ryan(The General)are great and menacing as the villains in the film. Tom Atkins is wonderful as Michael Hunsaker,Roger's old friend. Steve Kahan(Capt. Ed Murphy),Mary Ellen Trainor(Psychologist),Ed Ross(Mendez),Darlene Love(Trish Murtaugh),Traci Wolfe(Rianne Murtaugh),Damon Hines(Nick Murtaugh),Ebonie Smith(Carrie Murtaugh),Lycia Naff(Dixie)and Al Leong give good performances as well.The direction by Richard Donner is brilliant,with Donner always moving the camera and giving the film a great style and tone to the film and Donner also does a great job with the Action scenes. Amazing direction by Donner.The score by Eric Clapton and Michael Kamen is masterful,powerful and one of the best scores in an Action film. A great score by Clapton and Kamen. I also loved the use of the classic Christmas song Jingle Bell Rock by Bobby Helms.In final word if you love Action films,Thrillers or films in general I highly suggest you see Lethal Weapon,a masterful start to a great series and a unforgettable Action classic that you can watch again and again. Highly Recommended. 10/10.

Lethal Weapon is the typical Hollywood popcorn action film: it wasn't the first and certainly not the last either. But it's kinda special. I dare to say that it is...superior to the other films of the genre? I mean, it is extremely dull, the characters motivations are certainly not convincing or cleverly explained, and the story arc is painfully cliché...but the hell, who cares? The targeted audience is perhaps very satisfied with the result. It is a dull action popcorn flick with lots of crude jokes on it. I really don't get the appeal of this kind of film, it offends my intellectual capacities, but i can understand why some people do like this one so much. The fans of the 'popcorn' sub-genre do _and the future ones will_ absolutely love it. Mel Gibson actually overacts a lot, and so Danny Glover does. But that aspect do actually made some sense, since the film is plain over the top. And the soundtrack is actually very good. I really like it. It brings to the film a entire new type of atmosphere, a more neo- romantic thriller one. So...it's worth of one watch, i guess. More than one, it's asking too much. 6.5/10

Cartooney and naive as funk, but why not? I have to admit I had a few drinks before watching though. Gibson and Glover's chemistry is the greatest strength of the film. Hilariously dated action aside, the only thing that really bothered me is the inconsistency with the tone. I have nothing against black comedy and brainless action, but the first bunch of scenes with a girl jumping off a balcony and suicidal Martin Riggs mourning his wife felt a bit out of place.

Despite having one of the lamest titles and tag lines of any successful action movie (and most bad ones) this movie goes far beyond the action genre.The plot is fairly basic. 2 mismatched cops are thrown together. Riggs is young, his wife is dead and is happily breaking every rule in the police man. Murtaugh is an older family man who is just doing the job till his retirement.They get involved in the death of a prostitute, who turns out to be Murtaugh's old army buddy's daughter.What makes this movie different is many fold. Firstly there are a lot of sub plots and issues that tie into the overall story. Such as Riggs suicidal tendencies and his special forces military training. It is not just an ad-on, but forms part of a character arc for Riggs.There is also the police investigation. It is like real police work. Based on guess work, in exact, but no incredible plot twists. Most police work involves arresting the person standing over the dead body with a bloody knife shouting "I did it". This story shows how police try and work through something tricky but solvable by simple good police work.Then there is the action. Other than Mel Gibson pretending he knows Jujitsu the action is both realistic and exciting (no situations where 2 people shoot at each other, only the good guy hits, rather it is about the strategy, the chase and so on).Finally there is the humour. Jokes are understated and perfect for Mel.Oh wait...girls, you get to see Mel's naked bottom.....when he was young and sexy.This movie works at so many different levels (from naked bottoms up to great character development) that it will be enjoyed by many people. Also, do a search online for the movie script and you will see the script writer Shane Black needs to cut down on the coffee.The worst part of this movie is the terrible sequels and carbon copy movies that came later.

Review title: Lethal Weapon is the ultimate buddy-cop film.
Review_body: Murtaugh (Glover), is a hard working family man. Riggs (Gibson) is a suicidal maniac. They both hate working with others. Their differences cause major rifts. Their bickering, squabbling and conflicting ideals make their current objective a thrilling experience. The story is simple, but strong, the leads cops driving it until the end credits. Murtaugh's anger towards Riggs is funny. On the flip side Riggs's troubled past is touching. It dips a little in to dark comedy, but not so much that it takes away what emotion it carries. Murtaugh might be too old for this ..., but we're not. Riggs and his partner are characters that stick around, more so than John McClane or Axel Foley.

Review title: "Well, I haven't killed you yet." - My personal favorite 80's buddy cop action flick of all time
Review_body: On my birthday , while celebrating I watch another 80's action personal favorite action buddy cop flick of all time Lethal Weapon (1987). I love, love this film to death. The one and the only best film in the franchise 80's it is filled with Lethal bad-ass action sequences that you think and imagine your in the movie. It is filled with rush, excitement, entertainment, it has Christmas, Mel Gibson, Danny Glover and Gary Busey in the most excitement action flick of all time. It is Roger's 50 birthday in this movie so we both have birthday today.Lethal Weapon was written by Shane Black (Predator) and directed from Richard Donner who directed great this film. It has ton's of action, references back on Vietnam war, explosions gun battles. There is a lot of automatic weapons, grenades, hand guns and they are used well.This movie spawned 3 sequels and a TV series, so popular this movie become. It is very fun action film. It has little humor, action and little drama in it. It is filled with so many classic moments: I love the desert action sequences that was the best in the film. When Riggs and Murtaugh attempt to rescue Murtaugh's daughter Rianne (Traci Wolfe) in the desert, Riggs uses Heckler & Koch PSG-1 sniper rifle, like a sniper he is and kills many bad guys. Rianne steals a limousine and a chopper chases her. I love the torture scene in which Mr. Joshua (Gary Busey) tortures Riggs under the shower Electric Shock torture memorable scene. You can see this scene in The Last Boy Scout (1991) with Bruce Willis in which his daughter Darien is watching this movie. Great explosion you see Dixie's house been blow practical effect, real explosion. I love the music tune theme by Michael Kamen.Lethal Weapon (1987) and the first Die Hard (1988) are the best action movies ever made. I miss the '80's , this was my childhood film with Under Siege (1992) I watched them constantly as a kid. This was Mel Gibson's action movie with The Road Warrior (1981) that made him in to an action star. Predator 2 and Lethal Weapon made Danny Glover in to action star. The best bad-ass is Gary Busey as Mr. Joshua as bad-ass character. The man can play so well.A young girl jumps out of the building and kill her self. LAPD Sergeant Roger Murtaugh (Danny Glover) get's the case and find's out, she is a daughter of one of his Vietnam buddy's back from Nam who saved his life. Murtaugh is calm type and family man, decides to work on this case to find a clue. He get's team up with LAPD Detective Martin Riggs (Mel Gibson), a cop and former Special Forces sniper who lives on the ragged edge and who is a suicidal transfer from narcotics to homicide. The suicide of a young girl turns out to be a murder, she was poisoned by overdose they uncover a drug smuggling ring that involves a criminal gang comprised of mercenaries and former members of a CIA / special forces "Black Ops" unit with ties to the Vietnam War. These guys will turn up the heat. The fight between Mr. Joshua and Riggs is a bad-ass in the finale I love it.For the people who hate Christmas: "Goddamn Christmas!" Mr. Joshua (Gary Busey) shoots a T.V. displaying a Christmas commercial with his Colt XM177 Commando at Murtaugh's home. He destroys a police car with his machine riffle. For me Gary Busey steals the show. I love the guy and love he re teamed with Danny Glover in Predator 2. I miss these kind of movies action type now days. Today is nothing but lousy, lazy CGI. I want movies like this back: First Blood, Rambo: First Blood Part II, Cobra, Lethal Weapon, Predator, The Terminator, Bloodsport, Kickboxer, Cyborg, Aliens, Die Hard, The Terminator, RoboCop, The Killer and many more action movies from the 80's those are my movies that I enjoy watching them.Lethal Weapon (1987) is the best bad-ass action flick from the 80's my all time favorite action film. I love, love this film to death. A bus hit's a bad-guys car and his car with grenades explodes bad-ass best explosion sequence in the film ever. I have this film on Blu-ray theatrical cut and Director's cut on VHS I prefer the theatrical cut of the movie.

Mel Gibson delivers in this first of a series revolving around detective Martin Riggs, ex-Special Forces soldier, and his relationship with Danny Glover, aging police detective Roger Murtaugh with a family to protect.You discover that Riggs recently lost his wife, which has given him no fear of dying. He drinks too much, plays russian roulette, and takes no crap from anyone. But he's got a funny side too that Gibson delivers on perfectly. Gibson delivers the perfect mix of crazy and sane that is balanced out wonderfully by Glover. They have excellent chemistry and end up working well together to fight the bad guys.Gary Busey delivers as one of the key bad guys. Several scenes show you that this guy is just as crazy as Riggs. They have a psycho Commander leading his soldiers, and he commands Busey to do his bidding.The back and forth lead to a highly anticipated final battle, mano a mano, between the crazy duo. Who will win out? Well, since they went on to make multiple Leathal Weapons, you are pretty assured that Hollywood will prevail and leave you cheering. The ending is similar to several Mission Impossible ones.All told, great acting by the stars. Decent storyline of good vs evil. Gibson in his youth. A satisfying ending. A solid start to a terrific series. Enjoy Lethal Weapon.

Review title: Action, good lookin' guys and funny writing...
Review_body: So, there's nothing about this movie that you can't like. Excellent writing, directing and acting. Mel Gibson gives one of his best performances as Martin Riggs, and Danny Glover introduces himself in the first installation of the four 'Lethal Weapon'series as Sgt. Roger Murtaugh.For back in the late '80s, the action sequences are really quite good, and the acting is excellent. Although it's not my favorite of the four installments in the continuing story of Riggs and Murtaugh, it still has heart, and good direction for an action comedy such as this.It's not a cheap blow 'em up kinda flick. It's got all the right elements that you'd be looking for, in a man clan film, and it's well done. I enjoyed it, and will continue to enjoy it for many years to come.

One of the films that marked the decade.Mel Gibson and Danny Glover are a great acting duo, they make these characters and this movie so interesting and fun. The main characters are simply great, but the side characters are great here as well.There's action, humor and emotion here and it all together gives this film some timeless charm. Danny Glover is great in the role of a conservative family man who is given Martin Riggs as a partner, a burnt-out cop who seems suicidal.The atmosphere is fun, and the action scenes are brilliantly directed, the violence is brutal, bloody, just the way it should be in an action movie.The soundtrack contributes to the atmosphere of the film making it even more fun and giving it an extra dimension. Interesting characters, a fun story, great actors and a soundtrack that fits the film perfectly.An unforgettable cult classic that marked the decade.

Lethal Weapon is an excellent movie.  Danny Glover and Mel Gibson make a great team and I enjoyed them together from the first second the movie started, to the last second it ended.  They do really good together.  This movie started off some good sequels.  The plot is good and creative. The acting is excellent.  The direction is very good.Overall the whole movie works out smoothly and i enjoyed every moment of it. Rating 10 out of 10.

'Lethal Weapon' is another film franchise I've never had the chance to watch and so this review is based on my first viewing of this film. I will say right here that 'Lethal Weapon' is one of the best action films of the 80's, behind the obvious Die Hard and the obvious Terminator. The characters in the film are extremely great and this is one of the bigger positives from the film. The action in the film is great as was the cinematography until the final fight between Riggs and Joshua, which I say was a great fight but the camera movement was all over the place. It was sad, as the film duel would've looked brilliant. Apart from this, the film was brilliant and I liked the chemistry between Mel Gibson's Riggs and Danny Glover's Roger. That was my favorite part of the entire film. The script was great and the directing and acting were superbDefinite must see film for all die hard action fans!

Review title: A bare plot becomes a playground for powerful characters and a smart director
Review_body: Even a forgettable potboiler can become a great piece of entertainment if it brings together creative minds. Richard Donner's direction and Mel Gibson and Danny Glover's acting elevate "Lethal Weapon" into something more than the sum of its parts. Shane Black's script is polished and professional, largely free of extraneous elements or logical leaps. But the plot it conveys is as hackneyed as crime fare gets: a simple drug deal sloppily adorned with prostitutes. It has less flair and intrigue than a side mission in a "Grand Theft Auto" game. Happily, it's not where Black and Donner and Gibson place their focus.Even people who have not seen "Lethal Weapon" know it as one of the first movies in which a mismatched pair of cops are thrust together and form an unlikely friendship. And even before this gimmick became one of the biggest clichés in entertainment, it was already corny and obvious. The characters are drawn in glaring, unambiguous colors: Gibson is incredibly temperamental and reckless, and Danny Glover is an equally-incredibly contented family man. Glover's birthday gathering around a bubble bath is ridiculous, but it's an efficient way to link his character in an instant to all things good and comfortable and domestic. We know what he's about before he utters a word. Gibson doesn't utter, he shouts maniacally, but his character is also defined through exaggerated imagery. He stands unflinching in a hail of bullets, then watches TV alone on Christmas with a bottle of scotch and a loaded gun. (Incidentally, count the TVs in this film. They're everywhere. And when one gets destroyed, another one turns up— twice!) Surely even Marlowe and Spade had more humanity than this cartoon-watching cartoon of a cop. But "Lethal Weapon" doesn't need Gibson to be real any more than it needs a great plot, because its focus is unwaveringly fixed on just one thing: the chemistry between the cops.Donner is famous for infusing unreal characters with humanity. He brought out the sensitivity and aching in the Man of Steel. He's the perfect director to kindle the sparks that fly between Gibson and Glover. Donner ensures that one or both are always at the center of the action, which is not over when the bodies hit the floor or when the dust settles, but when Gibson and Glover share a quip and an affectionate look. As they grow closer, even the formless plot begins to coalesce around them, becoming an unlikely extension of their lives; after Glover and Gibson bond over their memories of Vietnam, it is revealed that the bad guys learned their tricks in Vietnam, too! When the prostitutes are finally out of the picture, Glover's beloved daughter steps into the sexualized victim role. It's absurd stuff, but very neatly and consciously done, and everyone involved commits to it in full.Unfortunately, the film ends with a small misstep. Gary Busey's superhuman villain is a third wheel to Glover and Gibson's relationship. His final, vaguely martial-artsy fight with Gibson strains credulity without adding to the central drama of the cops' friendship and rebirth. Its manufactured excess is one last reminder, though, that "Lethal Weapon"'s filmmakers know how to jazz up a genre picture.

Review title: "My luck's changing for the better every day. "
Review_body: Let it be known that I have seen "Lethal Weapon" many, many times. I've seen it so many times that I can annoy those around me by uttering lines in unison with the characters on screen. Yet, no matter how many times I watch it, I am always baffled at how quickly the hour and forty five minutes pass as I reach the end, feeling satisfied, yet yearning for more. That's the kind of movie this is. It's got an insane amount of re-playability, which is due, I suppose, to the fact that the story works on so many levels. "Lethal Weapon" is equal parts action movie, drama, comedy and buddy flick, all wrapped up nice and neatly in a perfectly sized and perfectly portioned little action-movie burrito. The perfect action film? The best of it's kind? It just may be.One thing is for sure, and that is that Richard Donner is the unsung hero of 1980's cinema. If it weren't for the groundwork he laid in this movie, the action genre -- as it played out in it's aftermath -- wouldn't have been quite as memorable or exciting. That's because Donner -- along with screenwriter Shane Black -- raised the bar, raised expectations and quenched the thirst of audiences. To have an action movie with real characters that you really cared about was a rarity for the time. Those looking for an all-encompassing movie, something that can be both a tearjerker and a nail-biter, will find just that in "Lethal Weapon" any time they view it. And at a stunning twenty-one years of age, it has yet to be outdone and hardly feels dated.Mel Gibson stars alongside Danny Glover, and it's hard to imagine one without the other. Would this film be as good had different actors been cast? It's doubtful. While Gibson brings the psychotic, alcoholic Martin Riggs to life almost naturally, it's Glover's grounded performance of family-man Roger Murtaugh that makes up the heart of the film. More than just a buddy-cop flick, "Lethal Weapon" is also a story about redemption, as Murtaugh welcomes a troubled Riggs into his family circle. It's Murtaugh's friendship that helps Riggs patch up his wounds, as he mourns the tragic loss of his wife to a fatal car accident. Even though the movie is "too manly to admit so", at it's core, it's a touching story about the power of friendship and loyalty.There's also action. Lots and lots of action. Donner constantly bombards us with explosions, gun-play, car crashes and so on, and manages to keep it fresh throughout. Whereas in other films an abundance of action can get tiresome, such is not the case here. The action bits in this film will keep you on the edge of your seat and glued to the screen. The movie is just so well-crafted in that sense. I can safely say that I, personally, am never bored with this film, and it's a testament as to why "Lethal Weapon" is the best of it's kind. Well, unless, we're talking about "Lethal Weapon 2", but that's a different story.

Review title: One of the Ones That Started it All
Review_body: If you have to see an action movie or buddy cop movie from the 80s, and you've already seen "Die Hard", then you absolutely must see "Lethal Weapon". It's one of my all-time favorites, if not my absolute favorite, and everything about is so watchable and memorable, and it never gets old no matter how many times you watch it. An absolute classic. The film was so influential that it spawned a whole host of copycats, such as "Red Heat", "Tango & Cash", "The Glimmer Man", "Bad Boys" its sequels, and others.You already know the plot: Two very different cops (Mel Gibson, Danny Glover) are assigned to work with each other, to take down some drug dealers. Matters are complicated however, when they kidnap one cop's daughter.This movie was perfect, especially for its time period, it still holds up today. The characters are still engaging, everyone delivers wonderful performances, there are great action sequences, and this movie is pretty much the epitome of character development. Amid the bullets and fighting, you get to see two very different characters, who are both in a way, the same character. Both cops have been on the force for a while, both have seen action, both are getting tired and looking for a way out. Both are good cops and people, but Murtaugh is tired of putting his life on the line, which is all Riggs knows how to do. Riggs and Murtaugh are two sides of the same coin, and they are one of the best on-screen duos ever to be seen. BothGibson's character, Martin Riggs, really brings most of the action, and when he's not dodging bullets or beating the crap out of someone, he's joking around and being cocky. Glover's character, Roger Murtaugh, is a skilled cop, but one who's tired of being a cop. Riggs is just tired of living. The two become embroiled in a drug investigation, and the pair engage in many antics along the way, such as a shootout at a Christmas tree lot, a death-defying jump off of a building, an intense chase along Hollywood Boulevard, and one final, brutal, legendary final fight scene that really compliments the tone of the whole film, and it really expresses the intensity and craziness of Riggs.Many refer to this as an action comedy, which is fair, but it really is more generous to the action genre than the comedy genre. There are some comedic moments, but this, and the second film are definitely more action-thriller oriented than comedy-oriented, but 3 and 4 are much more lighthearted. This film barely scrapes by as an action comedy, which is one of the things that makes it so good. It's just really brutally action-packed, probably as much as "Die Hard", but not to the point where it's over the top. Probably the perfect mix of action and storytelling, honestly. There were many memorable action scenes, such as the Christmas tree lot shootout, desert shootout, torture fight, club shootout and foot chase, and the final fight. In between those are many other brief instances of action and violence.Shane Black, a truly gifted script writer, has written some excellent films, and this is definitely one of, if not his actual, best. He establishes a really cool, dark, and gritty mood, and it compliments the character of Riggs so well. The film is really about two different, flawed characters who try to do the right thing, and succeed, learning about and accepting each other in the process. I should also note that Gary Busey delivers a pretty great performance as a villain, and he and Jet Li were probably the best of the four villains from the franchise.Richard Donner also delivers incredibly with the action sequences, adeptly staging and pacing the scenes, and swiftly moving us from one nail-biting scene to the next, while also using the lead actors' talents to the fullest, and Donner also handles the dramatic scenes quite well here, proving that he can capably handle just about any scenario he has to direct.Overall, I HIGHLY recommend this film, and except for a few brief instances of unnecessary nudity, and a lot of strong language, this film is just too good not to watch, and you owe it to yourself to give it a shot, at least once.

"Lethal Weapon" is just plain bad -- a dismal movie. Don't waste your time watching this one. Pass, you aren't missing anything. If you want to see a good movie of this sort, I would recommend "Above the Law" with Steven Seagal. "Lethal Weapon" just doesn't work on so many levels. I'm sorry I bought the set of 4, now I have to decide if I should risk any more time watching the sequels. I saw the sequels years ago and I thought they were average, but I never saw the first one until now, and it was bad. I had a feeling I would not like it.So many problems: it is too dark, too unrealistic, bad action scenes, hardly any normal women in the entire film (just one wife and several prostitutes which are treated poorly), the hero is a degenerate (not because of his fragile mental state which is nothing to mock, but because he is portrayed as interested in underage girls instead of ones near his own age), the plot is nonsensical (cops are invited over without a warrant then the suspect starts shooting at them; no backup cops ever around; that ending fight - so stupid), the Christmas motif and blasphemy is unwarranted -- the entire film is like some psychological trick to associate Christmas and Christ with the awful trash encompassed in this film. I'm not sure how this film got the great reputation it has or had. In summary, skip this one, 3/10 stars (and that may be generous).

It seems utterly incredible that this poor movie inspired a successful series. Badly directed, badly written and badly acted, it is more like a series of action movie clichés than a story. It borrows heavily from various previous superior films especially Dirty Harry. The 'suicidal jumper' scene in both films makes the comparison; in Dirty Harry, the scene was honest, but the inferior copy version, the scene ends with an unearned and deceptive pay-off, a cheat in other words. It is not possible to speak of the plot being contrived, but rather a series of implausible contrivances one after another. The basic idea, an unstable cop being allowed to continue working (and even being transferred to homicide!), is utterly absurd in itself but it gets worse. Basic procedures, such as handcuffing subdued criminals, are not adhered to, leading to two characters drawing weapons and having to be killed. People start shooting for no apparent reason, such as at the swimming pool. A hackneyed and unconvincing plot about a secret conspiracy emerges. An over the top shoot out in the desert, complete with helicopter. A gruesome (but laughable) torture scene. Gibson hurls a dead body across a room like a deadly weapon. A sub-machine gun fight takes place on a crowded free-way. And a final punch-up while the cops just look on.Everything about this film is clunky. It takes a long time for the story to get going and it is held together by certain convenient details. The dialogue is wooden, as is the acting (apart from the kids, who at least emerge with credit). The music is of the late 80s variety, and sounds very dated now.Nor are the action scenes very memorable, just a series of deeply contrived set pieces which neither look good nor convince. Situations are set-up just so a car can drive through a wall or hit a bus or explode. There is no artistry in any of this, and none of it lingers in the memory.A cartoon, and not a particularly good one.

Review title: Pow! Gibson and Glover and Donner and Blitzen!
Review_body: Viva Le Mel and Danny too!! An instant Christmas time classic! An action genre film to be enjoyed for years to come. What a team of unlikely hero's in this 'Lethal' of movies filmed in 87' or maybe 86'. This was the best of the Lethal's franchise. The idea was fresh with these two, and Mel was as big in this character as king Kong!! I know because of the recent situations with Gibson, on that they will disagree. I do love his stand on The Passion of the Christ, I live for HIM too. But I'm talking about his character portrayal the quintessential 'Gibson' man, in this box-office giant that if it had been someone else, it may have not done the type of business that it did. The feeling was for Martin Riggs. He wore it well. Losing the love of his life, you could feel the agony in his soul. The exchange between the two, Riggs and Murtaugh was an incredible balancing act. It would have to be or one end or the other would up end them both. A cop who's on the ragged edge almost explosive and a family man, who has a tight-nit group that would end up caring for a man in need of care. In return, he (riggs) with his quick -acting sharp-shooter trained conditioning, that actually came natural to his character and his ' wits' , would end-up, saving Roger from losing his life and that family . This was (I think) an original story that, like some others, for instance, " Indiana Jones ", " Predator " etc leaves you feeling a different emotion altogether. Sometimes these features should be left alone not made again and again until the real essence of the original story and characters has been recycled so many times that its water thin in the end. This has an alternate ending on the DVD which was perfect in my eyes, they should have used it. But money is 'king' even over art, right?The first is best. Shane Black made this right . Richard Donner directed it well. I recommend Lethal Weapon (****)

Review title: Great funny first half followed by a terrible 80's B-action movie
Review_body: After a lifetime of seeing this film in bits and pieces, whenever it happened to appear on TV, I finally saw it for the first time in its entirety, and the feelings are mixed.The basic premise of the movie is really bland. It should be enough to hear that that a movie was made in the 80s and that drugs and cops are involved to turn off a large number of people. Lethal Weapon has the markings of a typical 80s factory stamped action movie and it could have disappeared into obscurity, were it not for the two people at its centre: Mel Gibson and Danny Glover.Lethal Weapon is what has become known as a buddy-cop movie. The thing you need for a buddy cop movie is two good actors with a bit of chemistry and that is exactly what these two folks gave us. Nowadays, Mel's personal reputation almost squeezed him out of Hollywood, but do not forget, he is an actor with great charisma and Danny turned out to be just the right complement to his energy.The first part of the movie, when these two are first introduced and just work of each other, is the good part of the movie, but then the stupid starts. The cheesy 80s action stereotypes all come creeping in, complete with shooting rifles from the hip and unnecessary one on one fist fights. The dialogue turns to crap and the humour dies.This flick has a charm that keeps it a float, but it's a shame the story and the action is so poor.

Martin Riggs: "Well, what do you wanna hear, man? Do you wanna hear that sometimes I think about eatin' a bullet? Huh? Well, I do! I even got a special bullet for the occasion with a hollow point, look! Make sure it blows the back of my god damned head out and do the job right! Every single day I wake up and I think of a reason not to do it! Every single day! You know why I don't do it? This is gonna make you laugh! You know why I don't do it? The job! Doin' the job! Now that's the reason!" Los Angeles police sergeant Roger Murtaugh, who has just turned 50 years old, is assigned to investigate the death of Amanda Hunsaker, a prostitute who is one of the daughters of bank president Michael Hunsaker, a friend whom Roger has known since they were in the Vietnam War together, but Roger hasn't seen Michael in 12 years. Beginning with this investigation, Roger is assigned a new partner Sergeant Martin Riggs, who has been suicidal ever since his wife Victoria "Vicky" Lynn Riggs died in a car crash in 1984. Riggs and Murtaugh's investigation of Amanda's death reveals that she was murdered. Upon hearing of this, Michael tells Murtaugh that he would like for whoever is behind Amanda's murder to end up dead, like Amanda. Riggs and Murtaugh's investigation continues and it makes them the targets of Shadow Company, a group of former Vietnam War era mercenaries who now bring heroin into the Los Angeles County region. Shadow Company's leader, General Peter McAllister, and his right hand man, Mr. Joshua, want Riggs and Murtaugh dead, no matter what the cost.Just saw this last night as a part of my Lethal Weapon Saga movie nights and man, this one right here is the ultimate buddy cop film. This movie, in my opinion started the buddy cop genre which later spawned a whole lot of buddy cop films. From Tango & Cash, Bad Boys and Starsky & Hutch, it was all inspired by Lethal Weapon. What makes this film work incredibly is the chemistry between two leads: Mel Gibson as psychotic cop Martin Riggs and Danny Glover as "I'm too old fo' this sheet" Roger Murtaugh.I admit, I've never been really a fan of Mel Gibson as an actor, I like him better when he's behind the camera but this film changes it all. Tremendous acting by Gibson as well as Glover. Another reason why this film really clicked is the villainous Gary Busey as Mr. Joshua. A bad ass character portrayed by a bad ass actor. Mr. Joshua will go down as one of the greatest villains of all time.

Review title: A classic powerful 80's thriller with in your face high powered action and comedy
Review_body: Lethal Weapon is an absolutely brilliant film and it is the best one of the Lethal Weapon film series. Martin Riggs (Mel Gibson) who is a cop who has a psychotic past of suicide etc is no ordinary cop. This Vietnam Veteran turned cop is a man who is transferred to the LA PD to work as the new cop partner of Sgt Roger Murtaugh (Danny Glover) and is the best cop who'll keep his partner Sgt Roger Murtaugh, Murtaughs family and friends alive. Only one thing that is standing in the way to make Murtaugh and Riggs life hell is the dangerous and extremely malicious Joshua (Gary Busey). The film is filled with high powered in your face action and some great comedy especially Murtaughs line "Oh I'm too Old for this S**t which is absolutely hilarious and some other funny comedic scenes. Sgt Roger Murtaugh who is also a Vietnam veteran turned cop is also a guy who you don't want to mess with but is a bit more softer than the very powerful Dt Martin Riggs who knows how to deal with criminals excellently, take them down in combat and really has awesome skills in dealing with crime. Riggs is so powerful and his skills in martial arts is awesome and the way he uses his power in Ju Jitsu to fight against the dangerous and extremely malicious Joshua is absolutely amazing and brilliant. Riggs (Mel Gibson) is also very funny in this film saying hilarious things about Roger Murtaughs wifes cooking etc which also made me laugh. This buddy cop movie should not be missed and has lots of action and comedy in it. This film has some excellent acting by Mel Gibson, Danny Glover, Gary Busey, Mitchell Ryan, Tom Atkins, Darlene Love, Traci Wolfe and Jackie Swanson.

Riggs and Murtaugh the gold standard in buddy cops such a great team.
Gibson & Glover bring so much to the roles 30 years on "Still not to old for this " you know the rest .

Review title: A superb cop, buddy-buddy action film
Review_body: Considered for me one of the greatest quadrilogies of all and film of the 80s, Lethal Weapon is the action, cop buddy-buddy movie starring Mel Gibson as Seargant Martin Rigs, a loose cannon who having lost his wife to a car accident is on the ragged edge and lives in a trashy run down trailer near the beach with his dog Sam. Danny Glover plays Seargant Roger Murtagh, a 50 year coloured man with a family who lives in a middle class house. He and Riggs are teamed up to investigate a young girl who supposedly dived out of her window who was involved in drugs and making pornographic films. Soon they are on the trail of drugs and mercenaries.Throughout Riggs remains a lose cannon and goes off on one when he gets mad. Glover and Gibson make a fantastic duo when sparring with each other and coming to trust and become buddies right at the end of the film. There is great comic chemistry between them, which will have you in fits. Gary Busey as the principal villain makes a lasting impact.This is a superb first film with excellent and exciting action, great humour and a good story that all blend in seamlessly together. And two superb performances from Gibson and Glover that dosen't just make this your average action flick. One of the funniest and most exciting action films of it's time and for me still is now.

Review title: Quintessential action flick, Mel Gibson's breakout role...
Review_body: One of the better 80s cop films, this was Mel Gibson's breakout role (I liked the Mad Max films, but he was *perfect* here). This is one of the few series where all of the films worked; each one had qualities that outshone the others. Gibson's Riggs is best in the first film, though; the facial expressions, the dialogue, the body language: this is Mel Gibson at his best.Danny Glover, on the other hand, really seemed to warm/wake up in 2. He wasn't as solid in the first one, he felt too wooden and too generic.The script is sharp, good use of foreshadow and well-written in terms of plot and pacing. The film doesn't get boring, and doesn't really get unrealistic eitheras far as any action film doesn't;) Gary Busey plays his typical evil villain character, one that he plays so well at all times (though each character tends to be a branch on the same tree, so to speak).Some of the action was a little too generic. The final fight scene was way over the top, could've been clipped a bit.Overall: not much to say except that this is a good, solid action film. One worth watching; in fact, the whole series is most definitely worth watching. Some things could have been better, but most was right on. 7/10.

Review title: One of the greatest buddy films ever.
Review_body: If you can get past Mel Gibson's haircut then you will love this film. Lethal Weapon is the best of the cop buddy films and one of the originators of the modern formula. Mel Gibson and Danny Glover make a great team and their chemistry onscreen is genuine. Gary Busey makes a great villian in the evil Mr. Joshua. Plenty of action and wisecracks keep this movie moving and keep it light-hearted and fun. The second best of the Lethal Weapon films, (I think 4 is the best) Lethal Weapon just gets better with age. Bottom Line: If you like action and comedy wrapped up in one film, Lethal Weapon is a pretty good choice.

Review title: Bizzaro World Tubbs and Middle-age Crockett
Review_body:
Shane Black wrote a very tight screenplay, that was surprisingly solid for an 80's action vehicle, and that, for the most part, was well written, wonderfully pulpy. Unfortunately that was not enough to elevate it above its lot. It's literally 'Miami Vice' in L.A., or more because of Richard Donner's standard direction, a high-end "To Live and Die in L.A.". Hell, there's even a helicopter above the ocean scene that heavily reminded me of the opening credits to Magnum P.I. Black has since proven himself to be a more visually competent and exciting director than Donner, who is and has always been a mediocrity. One can only wonder what Black would've done with it...
Shane Black would revisit a similar theme nearly 30 years later with the much better looking, visually engaging, better acted, more cleverly written and arrestingly directed The Nice Guys, which was a terrific ride from start to finish. The much more droll 'Kiss Kiss Bang Bang', with Robert Downey, Jr. and Val Kilmer, was also more enjoyable than this dry-rub precursor, where the script was more interesting than the movie - kinda like watching a lackluster Hollywood adaptation of a mildly enjoyable pulp novel. What had potential on page ended up just another plaything to throw to the boys to play with.

Review title: A movie that goes back to a simpler time -- The 80's?
Review_body: This movie earns a ten, not because it's profound; it isn't... It earns a ten because it's a movie that set the bar. It introduced humor and family, to over the top action ( for the times) movies; Arguably. The next 15 years in action movies were based in the formulas for hits like this and Die Hard which came out the following season.I wish they had just let it lay as is; and stayed away from the sequels. Each Sequel diluted this movie. Until it became a joke on Always Sunny. But, if you've never seen it; it's not a bad way to spend some leisure time... Most guys from the 80's have seen this movie 10 times at least...

I suggest that everyone go see the "Director's Cut," which includes some supplemental scenes. This is really the best buddy-cop duo movie, and the one that initiated a series of copy-cats that never quite matched up. This is almost cartoonish at times and over the top, but in a good way. I don't believe anyone will ever be able to match Gary Busey's authentic-brand of crazy!! What really stands out about this is the dialogue and the memorable quotes. Of all the Lethal Weapons, this is my favorite. People alive today might not get many of the Vietnam-era references, which are numerous. But this movie is so cleverly put together, and with such timeliness and finesse.

Review title: It will take a heck of an action movie to beat Lethal Weapon
Review_body: Lethal Weapon shocked me at the same way as Die Hard did ( i'm sure you will find it's got practically the same Summary). There is NOTHING in the world that could beat this movie. Even though Die Hard was a relatively different movie than this it's about as good as this one. The story is in the same geniously spirit as Die Hard. I mean just the idea of pairing together two totally different kind of people and let them work together. I like the first one best because it really fits with the describing ''Lethal''. In Lethal 2 the humor was clearer with Joe Pesci and all. In Lethal 3 his role had got bigger. And in Lethal 4 the whole story is actually almost more funny than Lethal. So I like the original for one simple reason: It's tough! The fighting scenes have never been more violent then in this one ( OK OK OK the Lethal 4-end maybe ). But one things for sure: Mel Gibson is really a Lethal Weapon in this movie. The other parts are just more childish. Here it is a more grown-up story. Enough speaking. See Lethal Weapon. If you can buy the ''Lethal Weapon box'' with all three in directors cut. Don't ask  why just DO IT!

Right from the start the Jingle bell and the theme/Environment it was amazing.the chemistry of both was iconic love the development of friendship,Danny was amazing as family man and Mel was insane and bad-ass.the story was amazing the investigation and the Mysteries,the ending was fast paced and awesome,the fight at last and whole cat and mouse game was engaging and exciting,Whole movie was phenomenal it was entertaining and its a classic Buddy-cop Flick!

Review title: One action movie that lives up to its title.
Review_body: Lethal Weapon may be another one of those buddy-cop action pictures. This is one of them. You want action? You got action. And Lethal Weapon has the action. Lethal Weapon stars Danny Glover and Mel Gibson as Los Angeles detectives who are partner up to solve the case. They may hate, but that doesn't make the movie bad because this was just the beginning. The chemistry between Glover and Gibson are outstanding. The action sequences are thrilling and compelling. Writer Shane Black introduce some new characters that we seen before, but not in a steady action picture between there are lines of dialog that present humor, even between Glover and Gibson. The movie was directed by Richard Donner, who also made the 1976 horror classic, The Omen and the superhero 1978 picture, Superman. This time, his direction works. Here, a steady action picture like Lethal Weapon are why action movies back in the 1980's were exciting and thrilling like Die Hard. These action movies never have the computer special effects or CGI. If haven't seen Lethal Weapon, I will recommend the movie to those who never seen it before. ★★★★ 4 stars.

Review title: Gibson and Glover both made this movie worth watching!
Review_body: I don't have too much to say about this movie, but I'll do my best. So here it is: Lethal Weapon is basically a buddy cop movie about two mismatched cops working together on a case as they try to put a stop for a bunch of gangs for dealing with drugs on a Christmas holiday. What made this movie work is that both Mel Gibson and Danny Glover work so well together as we buy the chemistry between them; these two wonderful actors are the reason for making this movie worth watching. Gary Busey is a lot of fun as the villain as the rest of the cast all did for what they have to do. Richard Donner does a fine job directing the movie, but I mainly love his work on the first "Superman" movie as well as the sequel that he never completely finish as he only shot seventy-five percent of the movie if the producer didn't fired him so he can finish it for one hundred percent. The music by Michael Kamen is nothing special, but it is well done. The action in this movie is terrific, and the humor itself is alright. What didn't work is that the movie itself feels kind of slow, and which if they cut some things out so that I feel like I'm watching a fast paced buddy cop movie. That is just me, in my humble opinion. Also, I don't think its the greatest action movie of all time as it takes place around Christmas. So, I guess you can say that I like "Die Hard" more but I digress. Anyway, like I said, I don't have too much to say about "Lethal Weapon," but I do like to say that it is a fun movie, and both Gibson and Glover are wonderful together. I give it an 8 out of 10.

The eighties a time of big hair, bad clothes and worse music but the eighties also gave us Axel Foley, Arnie and of course Riggs and Murtagh. Lethal Weapon is an unashamed big, loud action movie but its more than this to with a smart plot and interesting characters. It's helped by having Gibson & Glover who are the best 'buddy' team since Redford & Newman, the action scenes are top quality but it's the interaction of these two that makes the movie. All the necessary ingredients for a great action blockbuster are present and correct chases, shootouts and a terrific final showdown. What is surprising is how little this film has dated it easily stands head and shoulders above recent efforts such as Bad Boys 2, XXX 2 etc. Top entertainment 8/10.Note - If possible see the directors cut which adds more depth to Riggs character with two quality scenes added.

This first film in the series is pointlessly violent, and no one can really act all that well. Riggs, played by a young Mel Gibson, is especially brooding. Murtaugh seems to be having trouble both speaking and walking, so he just starts yelling sounds. The male characters are Vietnam veterans, and the women either Moms or borderline stars - a common scenario for films of this period. You'll also hear small refrains of Eric Clapton's guitar that echo the popular completed tune it became years later. Cheesy and at times ridiculous, this film has aged well - not many do. Worth revisiting.

Review title: One of the great buddy movies!
Review_body: Roger Murtaugh (Danny Glover) is a police officer who has just turned 50 years old and is assigned to investigate the death of Amanda Hunsaker, the daughter of Michael (Tom Atkins) one of Murtaugh's old Vietnam buddy's that he hasn't seen in around 12 years. At the same time the department has assigned Murtaugh with a new partner, Martin Riggs (Mel Gibson) a man with a death wish who has been suffering with depression ever since his wife Victoria was killed in a car crash. Their investigations prove that Amanda Hunsaker was murdered and as they delve deeper they find themselves immersed in the world of organised drug trafficking and also find their original distrust and suspicion for each other grow into friendship.Perhaps not the greatest action movie ever, and in my opinion a little poorer than the first two sequels, Lethal Weapon' is an exceptional action/thriller and is definitely worth checking out. Lethal Weapon' is rather dark and gritty and deals with numerous interesting, and often emotional, scenes. Mel Gibson is great as the suicidal Martin Riggs and makes his character shine out in many scenes, including a school-yard sniper scene in the directors cut version. The audience can identify with Riggs and feel sympathy for him without being distracted from the main storyline. On top of this Danny Glover puts in a strong performance as the family man Murtaugh and adds a certain lightness to the movie without making it any less gritty. I personally feel that the pairing of Gibson and Glover is one of the all time greats in cinema, the characters of Riggs and Murtaugh go together exceptionally and the eventual trust and friendship that grows between the two is almost a beautiful thing to behold. A rather ingenious soundtrack really helps to add an air of humanity to certain scenes and compliments the Gibson/Glover partnership perfectly on many occasions. Credit must also go to Mitch Ryan who played Captain McAllister and Gary Busey who played Mr. Joshua as both portrayed their villainous characters magnificently and convincingly.The film moves at a steady pace and despite dragging on occasion is generally paced well enough to sustain the viewers interest. There is a lack of action early on in the movie but this does not hamper Lethal Weapon' in any way. The first half of the movie is almost more like a drama as we have to see if Riggs can keep his head together long enough for the duo to solve the crime. It's in the first half of the movie that the audience is treated to many emotional moments as the character of Riggs is fully investigated by director Richard Donner (this in my opinion is one of Donner's best films) and writer Shane Black. We learn so much about both characters in the first half that when the action portion of the movie gets going it's almost impossible not to feel for these characters who are putting their lives on the line. Donner's direction is exceptional though sometimes he lets himself down a little with some poor choices for camera angles or somewhat slow direction.There are few faults to this movie though people expecting gunfight after gunfight and explosion after explosion may be a little disappointed. Also the occasional dragging of the storyline makes some parts of the movie a little tedious, but overall the screenplay is very tight and there is a lot of useful and realistic dialogue. I would certainly recommend this to action movie fans and casual moviegoers. For fans of this I recommend the first two sequels as well. My rating for Lethal Weapon'  7.5/10

It's OK for a film of this genre...have not seen any of the sequels or prequels ( if any), but I hope they are better than this. Two lunatic cops are paired together. One, Glover, who appears sane ( but loses it frequently) has a house, kids, and a wife who needs to meet Betty Crocker or Chef Boy-Yar-Dee. The other makes no pretense at sanity (Gibson)...declared dangerous by a department shrink...other cops refuse to work with him out of fear. Sounds like a typical strike force cop if you grew up in the ghetto. Not exactly a match made in heaven, and not quite as satisfying as Laurel and Hardy, they bumble their way through a series of events where there is a lot of action, a lot of gunfire, and a lot of blood. But when the daughter of an old friend of Glover's winds up dead and the death is ruled as a homicide instead of a suicide, the two bumblers find themselves on the trail of a vicious drug and crime ring. For those who thrive on action in films and violence, this one is right up your alley. But it is not without its flaws. There is one scene where a man is threatening suicide by jumping from a tall building. Gibson apprehends him and they both jump into free-fall...but what the director holds out on is...they jump into an air-bag cushion that is already in place, not mentioned, and not visible to viewers until they fall into it. A 'cheap shot' scene like this one took away any credibility this film might have had for me...and holding out on that was an insult to the intelligence of the viewer. I grudgingly watched the rest after that, but that made me lose respect for the integrity of the film...or the lack of it. Watch it if you want, but be prepared for the ridiculous.

One of the movie genres which is the most popular in Hollywood is the action movie genre, movies like Star Wars (1977), Broken Arrow (1996), Independence Day (1996), The Fugitive (1993), and many more.  Personally, my favorite has always been Die Hard (1988) and considering some of the action movies we have been able to see quite recently, it always will be.  However, Lethal Weapon is another movie that I would consider as a good action movie. It isn't Die Hard, but it's pretty close and having been released one year before Die Hard, I give it credit for its styles which we can find in all of the Lethal Weapon movies.  These styles are a blend of action and comedy and a few emotional moments which keep the movie going and do not throw it off track.  Martin Riggs (Mel Gibson) is a cop who is very suicidal and whom many think is crazy.  He lives alone in his broken down trailer with no other friend than his guard dog.  During the day, he works undercover busting drug dealers or as a normal cop but doing crazy things like jumping off a roof with a man who had intended to do that in the first place.  On the other side, we have detective Roger Murtaugh (Danny Glover), an investigative cop who has just turned fifty.  Roger is married and father of three. 
  This is the set-up for the movie or as some people might call it, the excuse for allowing the movie to be.  The only thing is, these two men will have to meet one day if director Richard Donner wants his movie to be.  And this is where the emotional part of the movie comes in.  One night, in his trailer, Riggs brings his gun to his mouth and the only thing that keeps him from pulling the trigger is the picture of his wife who is deceased.  It seems to be the reason he wants to pull the trigger so that he may join her, but it also seems to keep him from shooting himself.  On the other side, detective Murtaugh is investigating the death of a prostitute who turns out to be the daughter of a friend with whom he served in Vietnam.  However, after the autopsy of the dead girl, the apparent suicide seems to be a murder case after all.  At this point, the two men have not met but they will quite soon.  Riggs is assigned to Murtaugh as his new partner.  The two of them quickly meet when Murtaugh assaults Riggs when he takes out his gun in the police precinct believing Riggs was about to attack the department.  Murtaugh soon realizes that his partner is a mad man and might get him killed while they work.  Riggs, on the other hand, sees nothing crazy whatsoever in what manners he uses to defend himself or his partner as long as he gets the job done.  For him, that is the only thing that counts considering the fact that Riggs realizes he is suicidal.  There is a very intense scene in which Murtaugh is trying to push Riggs over the edge telling him he should kill himself for he believes Riggs is not willing to do it.  But he realizes, just like the viewer, that Riggs is very willing and that he shouldn't tempt him.  The comedy sets in after the two of them meet and this is what makes this movie so unique.  In Die Hard, we saw Bruce Willis making wisecracks every now and then which allowed the movie to be more relaxing and all the more entertaining.  In Lethal Weapon however, the two actors make jokes and funny remarks about their age, Glover's family, and many other subjects all along the movie which gives it a cool rhythm and a nice flow.    Danny Glover seems to be one of the best actors they could have gotten for the job of Murtaugh as he delivers the goods and gives his now famous line "I'm too old for this s***" quite often.  But Gibson is the only man there was for the role of Riggs.  He steals the movie with his tough uncaring attitude of wether he dies on the job or not.  His attitude in the movie is comparable to Connery's in The Untouchables (1987) as he is ready to do anything as long as that gets the job done.  Fnally, the only thing missing to complete the cast is the bad guy.  I this case, Gary Busey plays an evil wacko named Mr. Joshua who has a disfunction in his nervous system as he can take pain with no reaction and still keep fighting back until he is taken down.  Busey is as good as Gibson and this might be one of the movie's flaws, Busey's lack of screen-time.  The script could have been somewhat stronger but you can't have everything now can you.  Overall, it is a very cool action movie and is definitely worth a watch.

Review title: You should watch the quadrilogy in a row
Review_body:
Yep, you should watch all 4 movies in a row, and you will discover:
ConsistencyEvolution of the personae, but they are still themselvesNo plot hole in their own story/history (because it's the same producer)Over al it's Action packed, very funny, good acting and dialogues over all 4 movies!

If you've ever wondered what a true 80's action film looks like, you might wanna check this gruesome, torture flick, Lethal Weapon. A film about the 2 cop duo, Martin Riggs and
Robert Murtaugh while going through endless pain and shooting.Some of you may think It's just a simple one, but it isn't. It's not just about, but also feelings and life problems. Martin Riggs is trying to get over his dead wife via trying to prevent suicide and Robert is getting too old for any jobs and is thinking about retiriment. Those things are executed perfectly in the film.This film has lots of things that make the sequels pale in comparison, so it's a flick you should watch if you wanna have your night entertained.

This is a wonderful movie. It has been praised for it action, comedy, acting. Practically every element ha received a favorable call out in at least one -- usually many -- of these comments. The truth (abolute and not subjective) is that it is all terrific. My favorite part is Gibson. He is beyond gorgeous and does a wonderful job here. One can easily believe that this led to his being cast as Hamlet. Loved Mel, loved the movie and despite being in the category of fan least likely to love it (older,female, professional), I love it a lot. I have mixed feelings about Glover but he was born to play this part and Mel, well, I'm just glad he was born and photographed. What a ride!

This movie is an onslaught of action; beginning with the opening scene death to the captivating end, it's a bombardment of epic scenes and high emotions. The plot is okay but what definitively stands out is Mel Gibson's performance. From start to finish, Martin Riggs (Mel Gibson) makes you feel excited just watching him. Whether it's with his psychotic bouts, unique demeanour or deep moments, his presence adds an energy to this movie that makes it both fun and insane (in a good way). His quality acting in Lethal Weapon is surely some of the best in cinema. Besides the amazing casting, the overall story is mediocre. In this film, though, it's the acting that makes it special. There are so many aspects to entertainment, and Lethal Weapon hit the mark with Mel as the lead.

Review title: 'Lethal Weapon' is a classic buddy cop flick
Review_body: Lethal Weapon begins with a woman jumping to her death from a roof. We then are introduced to Officer Murtaugh (Danny Glover) and family. His wife informs him that a buddy of his that he fought alongside in Vietnam is trying to reach him. When the audience is introduced to Officer Riggs (Mel Gibson) he is contemplating suicide. What ensues after is a rollercoaster ride of comedy and action and a great story. Lethal Weapon is the kind of movie that keeps you on the edge of your seat and you are always rooting for these two cops who are thrown together and forced to be partners but then help each other in the end. The film may have some cliches but it is well worth the view, and let's be honest, anything with Gary Busey as the villain is worth seeing.

Review title: The film that defined the action genre
Review_body: Compared to all the recent trash we get these days, Lethal Weapon is a classic. Brutal, funny and action packed, this really is an action film for the ages. But not all ages. Starting off with a tutorial into the more "Un-favourable" side of L.A. life and drug use, we are straight into the whole concept; this is a buddy movie. There are two main characters: the ever lovable Roger Murtaugh (as Danny Glover) a middle-aged man who doesn't want to lose his respectable life and Martin Riggs (Mel Gibson) a mad man who will do anything to stop crime (including jumping off a building). There target: drug kingpin Gary Busey. It's not a superb film: it's the style in which it's done. It's action-packed, funny, yet still stern, but is done to the effect that it's so enjoyable. It really is hard not to love it. An action-packed, violent comedy, Lethal Weapon defined action films and is a lovable classic that should be appreciated by anyone old enough to handle it. Overall: 9 out of 10

Review title: In the top 5 All time Best Cop movies!
Review_body:
This movie remains in the top 5 best Cop movies.
